"sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.staradvertiser.com/2024/07/09/breaking-news/trump-steps-up-attacks-on-harris-stays-silent-on-running-mate-pick/", "title": "Trump steps up attacks on Harris, stays silent on running mate pick | Honolulu Star-Advertiser", "body": "Supporters of Republican presidential candidate and former U.S. President Donald Trump attend a campaign rally at Trump's golf resort in Doral, Fla.\n\nRepublican presidential candidate Donald Trump ratcheted up his attacks on Vice President Kamala Harris at a rally near Miami today, trying to discredit her as the Democratic Party tussles over whether President Joe Biden should remain in the race.\n\nSpeaking at his golf club in Doral, Florida, Trump stayed mum on his planned choice for his running mate, although he name-checked Florida Senator Marco Rubio, who was in attendance and is a leading contender for the role, multiple times.\n\nTaking the stage nearly an hour late on a hot night, Trump blasted the 81-year-old Biden about his shaky debate performance on June 27, which prompted worries about his mental fitness for office and calls from some Democrats for him to step aside.\n\nBiden said he had a bad night and that he will not drop out of the presidential race.\n\nIn a mocking tone, Trump called Biden's choice of Harris, the first Black and woman vice president, his \"one brilliant decision,\" implying that she was so inept that Democrats were reluctant to replace Biden with her on the top of the ticket.\n\n\"It was an insurance policy, maybe the best insurance policy I've ever seen,\" Trump said. \"If Joe had picked someone even halfway competent, they would have bounced him from office years ago.\"\n\nTrump also accused Harris, a former U.S. Senator and California attorney general, of working with other Democrats on covering up Biden's alleged mental acuity issues. Biden has said he has the stamina and mental sharpness to do the job.\n\nTrump also said Harris's record would hurt her electoral chances, the latest sign that he and his Republican allies are starting an all-out assault on Harris to prepare for Biden possibly ending his re-election bid.\n\n\"I don't think Kamala Harris's California socialism is going to go down well with the people of Doral, the people of Miami or the people of Florida. Because in Florida we don't like socialism, we want our freedom,\" Trump said.\n\nThe Biden campaign accused Trump of lying about Harris, and said he was trying to deflect from growing attention paid to Project 2025, a conservative group's controversial plans to remake the presidency should Trump win the Nov. 5 election.\n\n\"Trump's bizarre and unhinged rants won't stop Vice President Harris from defending the Biden-Harris record and prosecuting the case against Donald Trump's extreme record,\" Biden campaign spokesperson Ammar Moussa said.\n\nGOLF CHALLENGE\n\nSeemingly joking, Trump challenged Biden to another debate, saying that it should be \"man to man, no moderators, no holds barred,\" and to 18 holes of golf - a reference to their argument during the debate over who was better at the sport.\n\n\"It will be among the most watched sporting events in history, maybe bigger than the Ryder Cup or even the Masters,\" Trump said, adding that he would give Biden 20 strokes.\n\nThe Biden campaign dismissed Trump's golf challenge as a stunt. They said Biden, who gave a speech at the NATO summit in Washington today vowing to defend Ukraine against Russian President Vladimir Putin's invasion, was too busy governing.\n\n\"We'd challenge Donald Trump to stand up to Putin, but he bent the knee to him,\" said campaign spokesperson James Singer.\n\nTrump praised what he called an \"incredible decision\" by the Supreme Court last week determining that he could not be prosecuted for actions within his constitutional powers as president, a landmark decision that could have broad implications for the criminal charges he is facing.\n\nBiden called the ruling \"a dangerous precedent\" because the power of the presidency will no longer be constrained by law.\n\nCalling the prosecutions against him politically motivated, Trump said he had \"great respect for the courage\" shown by the conservative justices who ruled in his favor. \"They have great intellect and great insight, incredible insight,\" he said.\n\nOn Saturday, the former president will travel to Pennsylvania for an afternoon rally in Butler, just outside of Pittsburgh, where the focus will be on any hint - or announcement - about whom he will pick as vice president.\n\nRubio, Ohio Senator J.D. Vance and North Dakota Governor Doug Burgum are seen as the leading contenders to join Trump on the Republican ticket. Trump said this week that he would likely make a decision \"a little before\" or during the Republican Party's national convention, which kicks off on July 15.\n\nCalling out Rubio by name, Trump pointed out the large number of journalists in attendance. \"I think they probably think I'm going to be announcing that Marco is going to be vice president, because that's a lot of press,\" he {"uri": "2024-07-416869883", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "02:48:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T02:48:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T02:48:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2024/07/09/donald-trump-miami-rally-debate-joe-biden/74344647007/", "title": "Donald Trump challenges Joe Biden to another debate, attacks immigrants: 4 takeaways from Miami rally", "body": "Project 2025 is a detailed plan by conservative groups to reshape the federal government if Donald Trump wins the election in November.\n\nWASHINGTON - Former President Donald Trump returned to the campaign trail Tuesday and mockingly challenged President Joe Biden to another debate in the wake of the president's rocky performance last month.\n\nTaunting Democrats who want Biden to drop out and allow Vice President Kamala Harris or another Democrat to enter the ring, Trump said during a sweltering Florida campaign stop he would give the incumbent president a chance to \"redeem himself\" with another debate - this week.\n\n\"This time it will be man-to-man - no moderators, no holds barred,\" Trump told Florida supporters gathered at the Trump National Doral Golf Club Miami.\n\nBiden and Trump have already agreed to a Sept. 10 debate to be sponsored by ABC News.\n\nBut Trump didn't only bash Biden and Harris during the Florida rally. He also again used dehumanizing language about undocumented immigrants as he laid out his border priorities for a second term. Trump has long vowed mass deportations across the country if he returns to the White House, and border debates have taken center stage during his third White House bid.\n\nHere are four key takeaways from Trump's Florida campaign rally.\n\nBashing Biden while he's down\n\nTrump, who has laid low in recent days as Democrats debated Biden's age and mental fitness, sought to take full advantage of concerns from Democratic voters and lawmakers.\n\nTrump accused Biden of being a \"part-time president\" in front of his crowd of supporters after his 2024 rival struggled to articulate his pitch to Americans on the debate stage. During his speech, Trump said his opponents are \"having a full-scale breakdown\" because \"they can't decide which of their candidates is more unfit to be president,\" Biden or Harris.\n\nSeveral Democrats in Congress have suggested that Biden withdraw, fearing that his falling poll numbers will take them all down on Election Day. Biden has said that Democratic disunity is the bigger threat, and he has urged the party to stick with him.\n\nA CBS/You Gov national survey conducted in the days after the debate found that 72% of voters do not believe Biden has the mental or cognitive health to serve as president, as well as nearly half of his own party. That was up seven points from the beginning of June.\n\nThe Biden campaign said Trump's debate proposal was not serious, only part of a performance that included extended comments about golf and references to fictional serial killer Hannibal Lecter. Trump during his speech made fun of Biden by challenging him to a golf match at Doral.\n\n\"Joe Biden doesn't have time for Donald Trump's weird antics - he's busy leading America and defending the free world,\" said Biden spokesperson James Singer.\n\nTargeting Harris, just in case\n\nTrump, who said Monday that Biden may well hang on to the nomination, spent most of the Florida rally attacking the incumbent - but also found time to go after his potential replacement, Harris.\n\nAt one point, Trump claimed that some Democrats would be reluctant to elevate Harris - and that's why Biden picked her in the first place. \"The best insurance policy I've ever seen,\" Trump said.\n\nDuring a campaign event earlier in the day on Tuesday in Las Vegas, Harris knocked the former president, alleging that he \"wants to turn our democracy into a dictatorship.\"\n\nA poll conducted last week by the firm Bendixen & Amandi Inc. showed that Harris could narrowly beat Trump in November. In the national survey conducted by the Democratic pollster, she would edge out Trump, 42% - 41%. The survey showed 12% undecided and 3% support going to third-party candidates.\n\nAttacking undocumented immigrants\n\nTrump also noted that Biden tapped Harris earlier in his administration to take on an issue that's at the heart of the presidential campaign: The southern border.\n\nRepeatedly assailing illegal border crossings and accusing migrants of widely committing crimes, Trump said immigration will be a top issue regardless of his opponent.\n\nIt's not the first time in recent months Trump has used the rhetoric against migrants. Trump told crowds in June that he that he has floated the idea of a migrant fight club to UFC President Dana White, calling migrants to the United States \"nasty\" and \"mean.\"\n\nTrump also told a New Hampshire crowd last year that immigrants who enter the U.S. illegally are \"poisoning the blood of our country.\" A 2019 USA Today analysis of more than five dozen of the former president's rallies found he had used words like 'invasion' and 'killer' to discuss immigrants at rallies 500 times.\n\nSidestepping the running mate search\n\nTrump also staged his Florida rally as he prepares to announce his running mate. It featured one of the top contenders: Sen. Marco Rubio, R-Fla.\n\nThe former president made several positive references to Rubio during the speech, noting at one point that the two of them played rough during the 2016 Republican primaries. \"We had a vicious campaign for a while,\" Trump said of the former opponent he once called \"Little Marco.\"\n\nDuring that campaign, Rubio called Trump a \"con man\" with \"small hands,\" but he became more supportive after Trump won the White House.\n\nDuring the rally, Trump joked about Rubio's chances to be the running mate, noting that his proposal to eliminate taxes on tips would need Senate approval: \"You may or may not be there to vote for it.\"\n\nOther vice presidential contenders include Ohio Sen. J.D. Vance and North Dakota Gov. Doug Burgum.\n\nTrump said he may announce his decision just before or during the Republican convention, which opens Monday in Milwaukee.", "source": {"uri": "usatoday.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8218005386", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "04:44:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T04:44:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T04:40:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2781526/", "title": "Trump teases his VP pick while taking particular aim at Kamala Harris - ExBulletin", "body": "President Joe Biden's poor performance in the debate not only put Donald Trump's long-awaited announcement of his vice presidential running mate on hold.\n\nThe fallout, which has included a cycle of inexorably bad news for Biden, has also provided Trump with an opportunity to take stock of what may be the most important decision of his bid to return to the White House.\n\nTrump acknowledged as much Monday night. Two weeks after telling reporters he had made his decision, he told Fox News' Sean Hannity that he was still weighing his options. Trump said the debate and uncertainty over whether Biden would be the Democratic nominee had emerged as a last-minute factor in his deliberations.\n\nFormer President Donald Trump leaves a campaign rally at Trump National Doral Golf Club in Doral, Florida, on Tuesday.Joe Raedle/Getty Images\n\n\"I haven't made a final decision yet, but I have some ideas about where we're going,\" Trump said in a phone interview for Hannity's show. \"And kind of, you know, we wanted to see what they do, to be honest. Because, you know, it might make a difference. I don't know. I'm not sure it would, but some people are saying that Trump is waiting to see what happens with corrupt Joe Biden, and we'll see what happens with Biden.\"\n\nTrump's teasing continued Tuesday night with a rally in Doral, Florida, where he apparently hurled more sharp insults at Vice President Kamala Harris, who could be his general election opponent if Biden withdraws.\n\nThe location also fueled speculation that Trump was poised to select Sen. Marco Rubio, who, like Sen. J.D. Vance of Ohio and Gov. Doug Burgum of North Dakota, became a finalist and whose political base is near Miami.\n\nSen. Marco Rubio, R-Florida, attends a campaign rally for former President Donald Trump at Trump National Doral Golf Club in Doral, Fla., on Tuesday. Joe Raedle/Getty Images\n\nRubio addressed the rally audience two hours before Trump took the stage, shortly after Trump's campaign sent a fundraising email suggesting his announcement could come at the event.\n\nThis never happened, although Trump playfully alluded to the speculation.\n\nI think they probably think I'm going to announce that Marco is going to be vice president, because that's a lot of press, Trump said at one point.\n\nQuestions about Biden's fitness to last four more years in the White House have dominated the political landscape since his June 27 debate with Trump in Atlanta. Biden, 81, had a hoarse voice and a slack jaw and appeared to lose his train of thought at times during the 90-minute event.\n\nSome Democrats have called for Biden to withdraw from the presidential race, while others have said he needs to do more to demonstrate he can beat Trump, 78, in a rematch of the 2020 election. Other discussions have focused on how Biden might be replaced and who might replace him. Harris and a group of Democratic governors have been mentioned as alternatives if Biden drops out of reelection.\n\nTrump's comments to Hannity suggest that his decision may now be influenced by whether he will run against a politically weakened Biden or against an entirely new Democratic ticket. A running mate who makes sense in a race against Biden and Harris might make less sense in a race against Harris or against someone else who appeals to a particular electorate.\n\nAt his Florida rally, Trump focused on Harris, whose first name he repeatedly mentioned more than usual in his campaign speeches, describing her as a left-wing ally of Sen. Bernie Sanders and saying she had failed as Biden's running mate. Trump also suggested that Biden would stay in the race because Democrats would prefer not to run with Harris at the top of their ticket.\n\nIf Joe had picked someone even halfway competent, they would have removed him from office years ago, Trump said. But they can't, because she has to be their second choice.\n\nA source close to Trump who has been in contact with him about the selection process does not believe the Biden fallout has changed the calculus around who to choose, the source said Tuesday.\n\nAnother Republican who spoke to Trump about the vice presidential selection process said: \"I don't think that's part of this plan, and I certainly haven't heard that's the plan. I think they have an idea of what they want to do and they're going to stick to that process.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Trump senior adviser Brian Hughes offered the same written response he has given to previous articles about the running mate search, namely that anyone who tells you who or when President Trump will pick his vice president is lying, unless that person's name is Donald J. Trump.\n\nOhio Republican Sen. J.D. Vance is on Trump's running mate list. Drew Angerer/Getty Images file\n\nA Republican with close ties to Trump's world said Vance, the new senator from Ohio, has the best case to make in any scenario the Republican ticket might face.\n\nAll I have seen and believe is [Democrats] According to the source, who was granted anonymity to share his candid observations, it would be best to partner with Kamala and a Midwestern governor like Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania. Someone like JD really expands the map and provides a safety net for the idea that turns to Kamala and someone like Shapiro who can go and reinforce the blue wall. So in that regard, he may be the only one who brings something interesting to the table, and given who he is and the way he communicates, you could see him just burning states.\n\nRubio is helping attract Latino voters, the source said, but the campaign is confident about his chances in Arizona and Nevada, key states with large Hispanic populations.\n\nDoug Burgum is, as most say, safe, the source said. He's not doing anything special, not helping you, not hurting you. He's kind of allowing Trump to shine.\n\nOthers see this as a selling point for Burgum.\n\nRubio and Vance have been more rhetoric than action, said a former senior Trump adviser who has remained close to him and has spoken with him about the search for a running mate. Burgum, a former independent tech executive, has really gotten things done as governor, as a leader, and the one thing about Burgum that I think really appeals to Trump is that he's not in this for the money or the fame.\n\nWhile Biden has given several interviews and made several campaign appearances since the debate in an effort to reassure nervous Democrats, Trump has been relatively quiet until Monday's call with Hannity. As one Trump adviser said Tuesday, campaign officials have been keen to stay away from Biden as he racks up headlines.\n\nTrump told Hannity he wants to wait until next week's Republican National Convention to reveal his choice, sticking to a timeline that has long been his preference.\n\n\"I think it'll probably be in the next week or so,\" Trump said, referring to the introduction of running mates. \"I'd love to do it at the convention. My people say it's a little complicated.\"\n\nTrump is enjoying the suspense and theater surrounding his choice and is likely thinking about how to leverage the moment to have the greatest impact, the source close to Trump said.\n\n\"It's hard to anticipate that with all the craziness going on with Biden, you really can't break through,\" the source said. He could choose Jesus Christ, and you're not going to break through now.\n\n\"I take his word for it last night that he really wants to do it at the convention,\" the source added. \"I think he wants to do it like a WWE walk-out, with smoke and a black screen and then the person comes out, because that would be good fucking TV.\"\n\nWhat Are The Main Benefits Of Comparing Car Insurance Quotes {"uri": "8217950630", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "03:47:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T03:47:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T03:47:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2024/07/09/donald-trump-miami-rally-debate-joe-biden/74344647007/", "title": "Donald Trump challenges Joe Biden to another debate, attacks immigrants: 4 takeaways from Miami rally", "body": "WASHINGTON - Former President Donald Trump returned to the campaign trail Tuesday and mockingly challenged President Joe Biden to another debate after the incumbent president's rocky performance last month.\n\nTaunting Democrats who want Biden to drop out and allow Vice President Kamala Harris or another Democrat to enter the ring, Trump said during a sweltering Florida campaign stop he would give the incumbent president a chance to \"redeem himself\" with another debate -- this week.\n\n\"This time it will be man-to-man -- no moderators, no holds barred,\" Trump told Florida supporters gathered at the Trump National Doral Golf Club Miami.\n\nBiden and Trump have already agreed to a Sept. 10 debate hosted by ABC News.\n\nBut Trump didn't only bash Biden and Harris during the Florida rally. He also again used dehumanizing language about undocumented immigrants as he laid out his border priorities for a second term. Trump has long vowed mass deportations across the country if he returns to the White House, and border debates have taken center stage during his third White House bid.\n\nHere are four key takeaways from Trump's Florida campaign rally.\n\nTrump, who has laid low in recent days as Democrats debated Biden's age and mental fitness, sought to take full advantage of concerns from Democratic voters and lawmakers.\n\nTrump accused Biden of being a \"part-time president\" in front of his supporters after his 2024 rival struggled to articulate his pitch to Americans on the debate stage. During his speech, Trump said his opponents are \"having a full-scale breakdown\" because \"they can't decide which of their candidates is more unfit to be president,\" Biden or Harris.\n\nSeveral Democrats in Congress have suggested that Biden withdraw, fearing that his falling poll numbers will take them all down on Election Day. Biden has said Democratic disunity is the bigger threat and urged the party to stick with him.\n\nA CBS/You Gov national survey conducted in the days after the debate found that 72% of voters do not believe Biden has the mental or cognitive health to serve as president, as well as nearly half of his party. That was up seven points from the beginning of June.\n\nThe Biden campaign said Trump's debate proposal was not serious, only part of a performance that included extended comments about golf and references to fictional serial killer Hannibal Lecter. Trump during his speech made fun of Biden by challenging him to a golf match at Doral.\n\n\"Joe Biden doesn't have time for Donald Trump's weird antics - he's busy leading America and defending the free world,\" said Biden spokesperson James Singer.\n\nTrump, who said Monday that Biden may well hang on to the nomination, spent most of the Florida rally attacking the incumbent - but also found time to go after his potential replacement, Harris.\n\nAt one point, Trump claimed that some Democrats would be reluctant to elevate Harris - and that's why Biden picked her in the first place. \"The best insurance policy I've ever seen,\" Trump said.\n\nDuring a campaign event earlier in the day on Tuesday in Las Vegas, Harris knocked the former president, alleging that he \"wants to turn our democracy into a dictatorship.\"\n\nA poll conducted last week by Bendixen & Amandi Inc. showed that Harris could narrowly beat Trump in November. In the national survey conducted by the Democratic pollster, she would edge out Trump, 42% to 41%. The survey showed 12% undecided and 3% support going to third-party candidates.\n\nTrump also noted that Biden tapped Harris earlier in his administration to take on an issue that's at the heart of the presidential campaign: The southern border.\n\nRepeatedly assailing illegal border crossings and falsely accusing migrants of widely committing crimes, Trump said immigration would be a top issue regardless of his opponent.\n\nIt's not the first time in recent months Trump has used the rhetoric against migrants. Trump told crowds in June that he has floated the idea of a migrant fight club to UFC President Dana White, calling immigrants to the United States \"nasty\" and \"mean.\"\n\nTrump also told a New Hampshire crowd last year that immigrants who enter the U.S. illegally are \"poisoning the blood of our country.\" A 2019 USA TODAY analysis of more than five dozen of the former president's rallies found he had used words like 'invasion' and 'killer' to discuss immigrants at rallies 500 times.\n\nTrump also staged his Florida rally as he prepares to announce his running mate. It featured one of the top contenders: Sen. Marco Rubio.\n\nThe former president made several positive references to Rubio during the speech, noting at one point that the two played rough during the 2016 Republican primaries. \"We had a vicious campaign for a while,\" Trump said of the former opponent he once called \"Little Marco.\"\n\nDuring that campaign, Rubio called Trump a \"con man\" with \"small hands,\" but he became more supportive after Trump won the White House.\n\nDuring the rally, Trump joked about Rubio's chances to be the running mate, noting that his proposal to eliminate taxes on tips would need Senate approval: \"You may or may not be there to vote for it.\"\n\nOther vice presidential contenders include Ohio Sen. J.D. Vance and North Dakota Gov. Doug Burgum.\n\nTrump said he may announce his decision just before or during the Republican convention, which opens Monday in Milwaukee.", "source": {"uri": "usatoday.com", "dataType": "news", 'Where is Barron? Stand up. Look at him! ... You're pretty popular. He may be more popular than Don and Eric. We gotta talk about this. Hey, Don, we've gotta talk about this huh?'\n\nThe 78-year-old ex-president said 'welcome to the scene, Barron,' and cracked that his youngest son 'had such a nice, easy life - now it's a little bit changed,' earning raucous cheers.\n\nBut Trump led the rally with a new challenge for President Joe Biden, 81, whose reelection campaign has been imperiled by his poor debate performance late last month.\n\nThe ex-president first said he wanted to debate Biden again - 'next week' - which would coincide with the Republican National Convention. Biden is due to debate Trump a second time already, but on September 10.\n\nTrump also said he wanted to play Biden in a game of golf - and staked $1 million on the deal.\n\nBarron Trump stands and pumps his fists as the crowd cheers at Tuesday night's Trump rally in Doral, Florida. Former President Donald Trump commented that the 18-year-old 'may be more popular than Don and Eric'\n\nBarron, the youngest son of the former president, earned raucous applause as former President Donald Trump told the crowd that it was the first campaign rally that the 18-year-old attended\n\nFormer President Donald Trump also challenged President Joe Biden to another debate - asking to have one next week - and a round of golf, saying he'd donate $1 million to the president's charity of choice\n\nBarron Trump waved to the crowd at Tuesday night's Trump rally held on the greens of the ex-president's Doral, Florida golf club. 'Welcome to the scene,' former President Donald Trump exclaimed from the podium\n\n'I'm also officially challenging Crooked Joe to an 18-hole golf match right here. On Doral's Blue Monster considered one of the greatest tournament golf courses anywhere in the world,' Trump said. 'It will be among the most-watched sporting events in history.'\n\nTrump said it could be bigger than the Ryder Cup or the Masters.\n\n'I will even give Joe Biden 10 strokes aside, 10 strokes, that's a lot. That means 20 strokes in case you don't play golf,' he continued.\n\n'And if he wins I will give the charity of his choice - any charity that he wants - 10 million dollars,' the ex-president added. 'And I bet he doesn't take the offer.'\n\nThe Biden campaign quickly clapped back, calling Trump's rally 'deranged.'\n\n'Joe Biden doesn't have time for Donald Trump's weird antics - he's busy leading America and defending the free world,' said campaign spokesperson James Singer.\n\nSinger noted that Trump's rally consisted of the ex-president 'inviting fictional serial killers to dinner, teasing lil' Marco Rubio, praising Project 2025 architect Tom Homan, and challenging the President of the United States to golf.'\n\nDonald Trump Jr. was one of the opening acts at the Tuesday night Trump rally in Doral, Florida. He noted how Democrats don't want Americans to own an AR-15 'but they gave a vegetable the nuclear codes'\n\n'Donald Trump is a liar, a convict, and a fraud only out for himself - par for the course.'\n\nTrump has stayed off the campaign trail for 10 days - holding his last rally in Chesapeake, Virginia the day after Biden's debate - allowing the Democratic president's campaign to implode as he stayed uncharacteristically quiet.\n\nThe ex-president was seen at Fourth of July festivities.\n\nAt the rally, Trump came aimed with a number of insults for his rival Tuesday night, surrounded by supporters and family members.\n\nDonald Trump Jr. was among those to warm up the crowd, noting how Democrats don't want Americans to own an AR-15, 'but they gave a vegetable the nuclear codes.'\n\nTrump Jr. was joined by his ex-wive Vanessa and three children - and his current fiance Kimberly Guilfoyle.\n\nEric Trump was also on hand.\n\nFormer President Donald Trump stoked speculation that he could choose Florida Sen. Marco Rubio - a 2016 rival - as his VP. Rubio warmed up the crowd ahead of Trump's arrival and then was seated front row at the Doral golf club\n\nAlso there - one of Trump's top veepstakes candidates: Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, a former 2016 rival.\n\nThroughout the night, Trump teased Rubio, seated front row.\n\n'I think they probably think I'm going to be announcing that Marco's going to be vice president,' the presumptive Republican nominee said.\n\nTrump trashed talked Vice President Kamala Harris and floated that Biden had put her in the position as an 'insurance policy.'\n\n'Maybe the best insurance policy I've ever seen, Marco,' Trump said. 'If Joe had picked someone at least halfway competent they would have bounced him for office years ago, but they can't because - she's gotta be, their second choice, has no chance.'\n\nAs the ex-president talked about his proposal to eliminate tax from tips - to shore up support from service industry workers, especially in swing states like Nevada, Trump stoked VP speculation again.\n\n'Marco you're going to vote for it, I hope. Well, you may or may not be there to vote for it. But you'll be involved,' Trump said, a nod to Rubio no longer being in the Senate.\n\nVice presidents, however, can cast a tie-breaking Senate vote.\n\nTrump is expected to announce his vice presidential pick within days.\n\nAlso on the list are North Dakota Gov. Doug Burgum, Sen. Tim Scott and Sen. J.D. {"uri": "8217894592", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "02:44:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T02:44:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T02:40:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/donald-trump-challenges-joe-biden-023449799.html", "title": "Donald Trump challenges Joe Biden to another debate, attacks immigrants: 4 takeaways from Miami rally", "body": "WASHINGTON - Former President Donald Trump returned to the campaign trail Tuesday and mockingly challenged President Joe Biden to another debate in the wake of the president's rocky performance last month.\n\nTaunting Democrats who want Biden to drop out and allow Vice President Kamala Harris or another Democrat to enter the ring, Trump said during a sweltering Florida campaign stop he would give the incumbent president a chance to \"redeem himself\" with another debate - this week.\n\n\"This time it will be man-to-man - no moderators, no holds barred,\" Trump told Florida supporters gathered at the Trump National Doral Golf Club Miami.\n\nBiden and Trump have already agreed to a Sept. 10 debate to be sponsored by ABC News.\n\nBut Trump didn't only bash Biden and Harris during the Florida rally. He also again used dehumanizing language about undocumented immigrants as he laid out his border priorities for a second term. Trump has long vowed mass deportations across the country if he returns to the White House, and border debates have taken center stage during his third White House bid.\n\nHere are four key takeaways from Trump's Florida campaign rally.\n\nTrump, who has laid low in recent days as Democrats debated Biden's age and mental fitness, sought to take full advantage of concerns from Democratic voters and lawmakers.\n\nTrump called Biden a \"part-time president\" in front of his crowd of supporters after his 2024 rival struggled to articulate his pitch to Americans on the debate stage. During his speech, Trump said his opponents are \"having a full-scale breakdown\" because \"they can't decide which of their candidates is more unfit to be president,\" Biden or Harris.\n\nSeveral Democrats in Congress have suggested that Biden withdraw, fearing that his falling poll numbers will take them all down on Election Day. Biden has said that Democratic disunity is the bigger threat, and he has urged the party to stick with him.\n\nA CBS/You Gov national survey conducted in the days after the debate found that 72% of voters do not believe Biden has the mental or cognitive health to serve as president, as well as nearly half of his own party. That was up seven points from the beginning of June.\n\nThe Biden campaign said Trump's debate proposal was not serious, only part of a performance that included extended comments about golf and references to fictional serial killer Hannibal Lecter. Trump during his speech made fun of Biden by challenging him to a golf match at Doral.\n\n\"Joe Biden doesn't have time for Donald Trump's weird antics - he's busy leading America and defending the free world,\" said Biden spokesperson James Singer.\n\nTrump, who said Monday that Biden may well hang on to the nomination, spent most of the Florida rally attacking the incumbent - but also found time to go after his potential replacement, Harris.\n\nAt one point, Trump claimed that some Democrats would be reluctant to elevate Harris - and that's why Biden picked her in the first place. \"The best insurance policy I've ever seen,\" Trump said.\n\nDuring a campaign event earlier in the day on Tuesday in Las Vegas, Harris knocked the former president, alleging that he \"wants to turn our democracy into a dictatorship.\"\n\nA poll conducted last week by the firm Bendixen & Amandi Inc. showed that Harris could narrowly beat Trump in November. In the national survey conducted by the Democratic pollster, she would edge out Trump, 42% - 41%. The survey showed 12% undecided and 3% support going to third-party candidates.\n\nTrump also noted that Biden earlier in his administration tapped Harris to take on an issue that's at the heart of the presidential campaign: The southern border.\n\nRepeatedly assailing illegal border crossings and accusing migrants of widely committing crimes, Trump said immigration will be a top issue regardless of who his opponent is.\n\nIt's not the first time in recent months Trump has used the rhetoric against migrants. Trump told crowds last month that he that he has floated the idea of a migrant fight club to UFC President Dana White, calling migrants to the United States \"nasty\" and \"mean.\"\n\nTrump also told a New Hampshire crowd last year that immigrants who enter the U.S. illegally are \"poisoning the blood of our country.\" A 2019 USA Today analysis of more than five dozen of the former president's rallies found he had used words like 'invasion' and 'killer' to discuss immigrants at rallies 500 times.\n\nTrump also staged his Florida rally as he prepares to announce his running mate. It featured one of the top contenders: Florida Sen. Marco Rubio.\n\nThe former president made several positive references to Rubio during the speech, noting at one point that the two of them played rough during the 2016 Republican primaries. \"We had a vicious campaign for a while,\" Trump said of the former opponent he once called \"Little Marco.\"\n\nDuring that campaign, Rubio called Trump a \"con man\" with \"small hands,\" but he became more supportive after Trump won the White House.\n\nDuring the rally, Trump joked about Rubio's chances to be the running mate, noting that his proposal to eliminate taxes on tips would need Senate approval: \"You may or may not be there to vote for it.\"\n\nOther vice presidential contenders include Ohio Sen. J.D. Vance and North Dakota Gov. Doug Burgum.\n\nTrump said he may announce his decision just before or during the Republican convention, which opens Monday in Milwaukee.\n\nContributing: Karissa Waddick and Rachel Barber, USA "-09-10", "textStart": 679, "textEnd": 687}], "sentiment": -0.0117647058823529, "wgt": 196, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8217871754", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "02:10:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T02:10:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T02:09:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://mb.com.ph/2024/7/10/trump-revels-in-democratic-turmoil-as-he-returns-to-campaign-trail-and-teases-vp-pick", "title": "Trump revels in Democratic turmoil as he returns to campaign trail and teases VP pick", "body": "MIAMI (AP) -- Former President Donald Trump on Tuesday reveled in the mounting turmoil surrounding President Joe Biden 's campaign in the wake of their debate and teased the expected announcement of his Republican running mate with one of the top contenders, Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, in attendance.\n\nRepublican presidential candidate former President Donald Trump speaks at a campaign rally at Trump National Doral Miami, Tuesday, July 9, 2024, in Doral, Fla. (AP Photo/Marta Lavandier)\n\nAfter days spent lying low, golfing and letting Democratic infighting play out in public, Trump used his return to the campaign trail in Florida to ratchet up his attacks on both Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris, indulging speculation that she could replace the president as the Democratic nominee this year and alleging, without evidence, that his son Hunter Biden is \"running our government\" and first lady Jill Biden \"is helping.\" Biden has repeatedly insisted he won't withdraw from the race.\n\nTrump rallied his supporters at one of his Miami-area golf courses as the presumptive Republican nominee nears a deadline to announce his running mate. But he appears in no rush, as much of the political world's attention is still centered on questions about Biden's ability to govern for another four-year term. Some Democrats have started calling for Biden to step down as their presumptive nominee following his dismal debate performance last month.\n\nTrump, speaking from the 10th hole of his course, challenged Biden to another debate or even a \"golf-off\" reviving an offbeat argument from their debate. But mostly, he rubbed in how their meetup left Biden's campaign facing a grim prognosis.\n\n\"Our victory was so absolute that Joe's own party now wants him to throw in the towel and surrender the presidency after a single 90-minute performance,\" Trump said Tuesday night. \"They want 'Crooked Joe' out of the race. It's a shame the way they're treating him. But don't feel sorry for him. He's a very bad guy.\"\n\nJames Singer, a spokesperson for Biden's campaign, responded to Trump with a series of challenges, saying in a statement that, \"We'd challenge Donald Trump to create jobs, but he lost 3 million. We'd challenge Donald Trump to stand up to Putin, but he bent the knee to him. We'd challenge Donald Trump to follow the law, but he breaks it.\"\n\nSinger also said, \"Joe Biden doesn't have time for Donald Trump's weird antics - he's busy leading America and defending the free world.\n\nTrump laced into Harris with more specifics than usual. She has become a focus of the former president and his allies as speculation has mounted that she would replace Biden as the Democratic nominee. Trump called her \"Laughing Kamala,\" and referred to the \"Biden-Harris administration,\" rather than just pinning actions on Biden as he had for months, and blamed Harris for the White House's immigration policies.\n\n\"Despite all the Democrat panic this week, the truth is, it doesn't matter who they nominate because we are going to beat any one of them in thundering landslides and this November's going to be amazing,\" he said.\n\nTrump, ever the showman, repeatedly played into the speculation that he might elevate Rubio to his ticket.\n\nRubio, a Miami native and one of the contenders for the vice presidential post, was among the Florida politicians who spoke at the event.\n\nAt one point, Trump marveled at the number of reporters in attendance and said, \"I think they probably think I'm going to be announcing that Marco is going to be vice president.\"\n\nLater, when he talked about his pledge to make tips tax-free, he remarked that Rubio \"may or may not be there to vote for it.\"\n\nRubio, the son of Cuban immigrants, is seen as a potential running mate who could help Trump as he tries to secure support from Hispanic Americans, a point the senator emphasized in his remarks as he switched several times in his remarks to Spanish.\n\nThe senator did not openly acknowledge any of the speculation about him joining Trump as a running mate. He instead skewered not only Biden, whom he called \"the figurehead of a left-wing government, shadow government,\" but Harris, whom he would need to debate head-on if he's chosen for Trump's ticket.\n\nRubio referred to Harris not by name at first but called her Biden's \"replacement\" and \"a real-life, verified left-winger.\" At another point in his remarks, he mocked the way Harris laughs.\n\nHe notably seemed to insert himself into Trump's signature \"Make America Great Again\" slogan by saying: \"Together, we're not just going to make it great again. We elect this man as president, we will make together America greater than it has ever been.\"\n\nThousands of people turned out in the humid summer evening for the rally. Attendees were fanning themselves and holding signs featuring Trump's mug shot, along with others that said, \"You're fired!\" -- Trump's signature phrase on his former reality show, \"The Apprentice.\"\n\nTrump's youngest child who recently turned 18, Barron, also made his first-ever appearance at one of his father's rallies. Trump implored his son to stand, with the young man pumping his fist a few times as Trump said, \"Welcome to the scene, Barron.\"\n\nOne attendee, 28-year-old Austin Stiglin, said he traveled from northern Florida to participate in his first Trump rally. He was wearing a star-patterned navy blue jacket and red pants and said he was \"tired of the left telling him to vote left just because I am gay.\"\n\n\"I have a lot more to say than just my sexual orientation,\" Stiglin said. \"I would like to vote for policies that support the United States.\"\n\nNicole Farrell, a 57-year-old immigrant from Trinidad, said she voted for Trump in 2020, \"but I was not a strong supporter like now. I just preferred him over Biden.\"\n\nFarrell said she specifically likes Trump's hardline immigration policies, which include plans for mass raids and the largest deportation operation in U.S. history.\n\n\"I am an immigrant but I came here legally. They need to come here legally,\" Farrell said of migrants coming to the U.S.\n\nBoth Biden, 81, and Trump, 78, are at least two decades older than most American presidents have been, according to the Pew Research Center, which said the median age for all U.S. presidents on their first inauguration is 55 years old. But that has not stopped Trump from arguing he is stronger than Biden, who repeatedly stumbled, paused and could not complete sentences at times during the June 27 debate. Trump was criticized by Democrats for making false statements during the debate about the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol and suggesting immigrants entering the U.S. illegally were taking so-called \"Black jobs\" and \"Hispanic jobs.\"", "source": {"uri": "mb.com.ph", "dataType": "news", "title": "Manila Bulletin"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": We elect this man as president, we will make together America greater than it has ever been.\"\n\nThousands of people turned out in the humid summer evening for the rally. Attendees were fanning themselves and holding signs featuring Trump's mug shot, along with others that said, \"You're fired!\" -- Trump's signature phrase on his former reality show, \"The Apprentice.\"\n\nTrump's youngest child who recently turned 18, Barron, also made his first-ever appearance at one of his father's rallies. Trump implored his son to stand, with the young man pumping his fist a few times as Trump said, \"Welcome to the scene, Barron.\"\n\nOne attendee, 28-year-old Austin Stiglin, said he traveled from northern Florida to participate in his first Trump rally. He was wearing a star-patterned navy blue jacket and red pants and said he was \"tired of the left telling him to vote left just because I am gay.\"\n\n\"I have a lot more to say than just my sexual orientation,\" Stiglin said. \"I would like to vote for policies that support the United States.\"\n\nNicole Farrell, a 57-year-old immigrant from Trinidad, said she voted for Trump in 2020, \"but I was not a strong supporter like now. I just preferred him over Biden.\"\n\nFarrell said she specifically likes Trump's hardline immigration policies, which include plans for mass raids and the largest deportation operation in U.S. history.\n\n\"I am an immigrant but I came here legally. They need to come here legally,\" Farrell said of migrants coming to the U.S.\n\nBoth Biden, 81, and Trump, 78, are at least two decades older than most American presidents have been, according to the Pew Research Center, which said the median age for all U.S. presidents on their first inauguration is 55 years old. {"uri": "8217872530", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "02:14:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T02:14:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T02:10:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/trump-challenges-biden-another-debate-011724768.html", "title": "Trump challenges Biden to another debate this week and golf match during Florida rally", "body": "Donald Trump challenged Joe Biden to another presidential debate \"this week\" and a golf match that he claimed would be \"bigger than the Ryder Cup or even the Masters\" during his latest campaign rally.\n\nTrump said he wanted to take on Biden in a debate that would be \"man to man, no moderators, no holds barred.\"\n\nThe former president took to the stage at Trump National Doral Golf Club in Miami, Florida -- which he described as \"one of the greatest golf courses on Earth\" -- in front of a large cheering crowd on Tuesday night.\n\nAt his first major rally in more than a week, Trump blasted President Biden for his poor performance in their debate last month, saying that it had been \"even according to the fake news media, the most decisive and overwhelming defeat in the history of presidential debates.\"\n\nBiden has remained adamant that he will stay on in the race for the White House, challenging senior Democrats to run against him at the Democratic National Convention, and saying that only \"The Lord Almighty\" could stop him from running.\n\n\"Even CNN said as I walked off the stage that it was one of the greatest performances they've ever seen. But it was sort of easy if you want to know the truth,\" Trump told supporters in Miami.\n\n\"But don't feel sorry for he's a very bad guy. He weaponized government. Remember that -- he's a very bad guy. Don't feel sorry for him. So tonight, I'm officially offering Joe the chance to redeem himself in front of the entire world,\" Trump said.\n\n\"Let's do another debate this week -- so that sleepy Joe Biden can prove to everyone all over the world that he has what it takes to be president,\" he added. \"But this time, it will be man to man, no moderators, no holds barred, just name the place, any time.\"\n\nThe first presidential debate in Atlanta on June 27 was widely seen as disastrous for Biden, 81, and has led to questions about his fitness to lead and ability to win reelection even within his own party.\n\nTrump, 78, went on to challenge Biden to an \"18-hole golf match\", something the two men clashed over bizarrely during the debate.\n\n\"It will be among the most watched sporting events in history, maybe bigger than the Ryder Cup or even the Masters,\" Trump declared.\n\n\"I will even give Joe Biden 10 strokes a side. 10 strokes, that's a lot. That means 20 strokes in case you don't play golf. I will give him 10 strokes a side and if he wins, I will give the charity of his choice, any charity that he wants, $1 million.\"\n\nBiden campaign spokesperson James Singer said Trump \"hasn't been seen in public for 12 days\" and is now \"challenging the President of the United State to play golf.\"\n\nSinger said the president would instead challenge Trump to create jobs, stand up to Russian President Vladimir Putin, and not break the law.\n\n\"Joe Biden doesn't have time for Trump's weird antics,\" he said in a statement. \"He's busy leading America and defending the free world.\"\n\nA day after the debate with Biden, Trump performed somewhat of a victory lap in Chesapeake, Virginia, where he piled in on the president, deriding him as \"grossly incompetent\" and a \"train wreck.\"\n\n\"The question every voter should be asking themselves today is not whether Joe Biden can survive a 90-minute debate performance, but whether America can survive four more years of crooked Joe Biden the White House,\" Trump said from Virginia on June 28.\n\n\"In fact, I don't know if we can really survive five more months.\"\n\nIndeed, the president has faced multiple calls, both publicly and privately from senior members of his own party, while the eyes of the world are on him during this week's NATO summit in Washington DC.\n\nA new poll shows Vice President Kamala Harris now has a better shot than Biden at defeating Trump in the 2024 election. The survey, conducted by the Democratic firm Bendixen & Amandi, showed Biden slightly behind Trump, 42 to 43 percent, with Harris inching past the former president 42 to 41 percent.\n\nTrump is expected to name his pick for vice president shortly, with just one week to go before the Republican National Convention on July 14.\n\nOhio Senator JD Vance and Florida Senator Marco Rubio are leading contenders to join Trump on the Republican ticket, people familiar with the matter have told Reuters, with North Dakota Governor Doug Burgum also still in the mix.\n\nRemarking on the amount of press attending his rally in Florida, Trump speculated that it was only due to the anticipation surrounding his choice for vice president.\n\n\"I think they probably think I'm going to be announcing that Marco [Rubio] is going to be vice president because that's a lot of press. {"uri": "8217834766", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "01:21:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T01:21:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T01:20:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2024-election/trump-teases-vp-pick-sharper-aim-kamala-harris-rcna160915", "title": "Trump teases his VP pick while taking sharper aim at Kamala Harris", "body": "Trump has been in no hurry to announce his running mate since Biden's rough debate performance, and the pause has also provided him an opportunity to gut-check his choice.\n\nPresident Joe Biden's poor debate performance has not only thrown Donald Trump's long-anticipated announcement of a vice presidential running mate into a holding pattern.\n\nThe fallout, which has included a relentlessly bad news cycle for Biden, has also provided Trump an opportunity to gut-check perhaps the biggest decision of his bid to return to the White House.\n\nTrump acknowledged as much Monday night. Two weeks after telling reporters that he had made up his mind, the former president told Fox News' Sean Hannity that he was still evaluating his options. Trump indicated that the debate -- and uncertainty about whether Biden will be the Democratic nominee -- had emerged as a last-minute factor in his deliberations.\n\n\"I haven't made a final decision, but I have some ideas as to where we're going,\" Trump said during a telephone interview for Hannity's primetime show. \"And a little bit, you know, we wanted to see what they're doing, to be honest. Because, you know, it might make a difference. I don't know. I'm not sure that it would, but there are those who say Trump's waiting until he finds out what's going to happen with crooked Joe Biden, and we'll see what happens with Biden.\"\n\nTrump's rollout tease continued Tuesday night with a rally in Doral, Florida, where he noticeably aimed sharper insults at Vice President Kamala Harris, who could be his general election opponent if Biden steps aside.\n\nThe location also fueled speculation that Trump was about to select Sen. Marco Rubio -- who along with Sen. JD Vance of Ohio and Gov. Doug Burgum of North Dakota, has emerged as a finalist, and whose political base is in nearby Miami.\n\nRubio addressed the rally audience two hours before Trump took the stage, not long after Trump's campaign sent out a fundraising email suggesting his announcement could come at the event.\n\nIt never did, though Trump playfully alluded to the speculation.\n\n\"I think they probably think I'm going to be announcing that Marco is going to be vice president, because that's a lot of press,\" Trump said at one point.\n\nQuestions about Biden's fitness to serve another four years have dominated the political landscape since his June 27 debate with Trump in Atlanta. Biden, 81, was raspy-voiced and slack-jawed and appeared to lose his train of thought at times during the 90-minute event.\n\nSome Democrats have called for Biden to step aside as the party's presidential nominee, while others have said he must do more to demonstrate that he is capable of beating Trump, 78, in a rematch of the 2020 election. Other conversations have focused on how Biden could be replaced -- and who might replace him. Harris and a crop of Democratic governors have been mentioned as alternatives should Biden drop his re-election bid.\n\nTrump's comments to Hannity hinted that his decision could now be swayed by the possibility of running against a politically weakened Biden or an altogether new Democratic ticket. A running mate who makes sense for a race against Biden and Harris might make less sense in a race against Harris or against someone else who appeals to a particular constituency.\n\nAt his Florida rally, Trump focused on Harris -- whose first name he repeatedly mispronounced -- more than he typically does in campaign speeches, describing her as a left-wing ally of Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt., and asserting that she has underperformed as Biden's vice president. Trump also suggested that Biden would remain in the race because Democrats would rather not run with Harris at the top of their ticket.\n\n\"If Joe had picked someone even halfway competent, they would have bounced him from office years ago,\" Trump said. \"But they can't, because she's got to be their second choice.\"\n\nA source close to Trump who has been in touch with him on the selection process said Tuesday that they did not believe the Biden fallout had changed the calculus around who to choose.\n\n\"I just don't think that's part of this, and I certainly have not heard that is the plan,\" said another Republican who has spoken to Trump about the vice presidential selection process. \"I think they have an idea of what they want to do, and are going to stick with that process.\"\n\nMeanwhile, senior Trump adviser Brian Hughes offered the same written reply he has for previous stories about the VP search -- that \"anyone telling you they know who or when President Trump will choose his VP is lying unless that person is named Donald J. Trump.\"\n\nA Republican who is closely tied to Trump world said that Vance, the freshman senator from Ohio, has the best case to make under any scenario the GOP ticket might face.\n\n\"Everything that I've seen and believe is [Democrats] would go with Kamala and a Midwestern governor like Josh Shapiro,\" of Pennsylvania, the source, who requested anonymity to share candid observations, added. \"Somebody like JD actually expands the map and is a backstop to the idea where it flips to Kamala and somebody like Shapiro who can go and reinforce the blue wall. So in that regard, he may be the only one that actually adds something of interest, and given who he is and how he communicates, you could see him just barn-burning states.\"\n\nRubio helps appeal to Latino voters, the source said, but the campaign is feeling confident about its chances in Arizona and Nevada, two swing states with large Hispanic populations.\n\n\"Doug Burgum is, as most say, safe,\" the source continued. \"He doesn't really do anything, doesn't help you, doesn't hurt you. He kind of allows Trump to shine.\"\n\nOthers see that as a selling point for Burgum.\n\nRubio and Vance \"have been more rhetoric than they've been substance,\" said one former senior Trump adviser, who remains close with the former president and has discussed the VP search with him. Burgum, an independently wealthy former tech executive, \"has actually gotten things done as a governor, as an executive, and the one thing about Burgum that I think really appeals to Trump is that he's not doing this for the money or for the fame.\"\n\nWhile Biden has done several interviews and made several campaign appearances since the debate as part of an effort to reassure nervous Democrats, Trump had kept a relatively low profile until Monday's call to Hannity. As one Trump adviser put it Tuesday, campaign officials have been eager to stay out of Biden's way while he racks up rough headlines.\n\nTrump told Hannity that he wants to wait until next week's Republican National Convention to reveal his choice -- sticking to a timeline that has long been his preference.\n\n\"I think probably within the next week,\" Trump said, referring to the running mate rollout. \"I'd love to do it during the convention. My people say that's a little complicated.\"\n\nTrump is enjoying the suspense and \"theatrics\" surrounding his pick and likely weighing how to \"leverage the moment to have the highest impact,\" the source close to Trump world said.\n\n\"It's been hard to anticipate that with all of the craziness happening with Biden that you really can't punch through,\" the source said. \"He could pick Jesus Christ, and you're not going to punch through right now.\"\n\n\"I do take him at his word that he said last night, which he really wants to do it at the convention,\" the source added. \"I think he wants to do it like a WWE walk-out, where there's smoke and a black screen and then the person appears, because that'd be good f---ing TV.\"", "source": {"uri": "nbcnews.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8218034869", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "05:11:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T05:11:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T05:10:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://cyprus-mail.com/2024/07/10/trump-attacks-kamala-harris-mocks-democrats/", "title": "Trump attacks Kamala Harris, mocks Democrats", "body": "Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump ratcheted up his attacks on Vice President Kamala Harris at a rally near Miami on Tuesday, trying to discredit her as the Democratic Party tussles over whether President Joe Biden should remain in the race.\n\nSpeaking at his golf club in Doral, Florida, Trump stayed mum on his planned choice for his running mate, although he name-checked Florida Senator Marco Rubio, who was in attendance and is a leading contender for the role, multiple times.\n\nTaking the stage nearly an hour late on a hot night, Trump blasted the 81-year-old Biden about his shaky debate performance on June 27, which prompted worries about his mental fitness for office and calls from some Democrats for him to step aside.\n\nBiden said he had a bad night and that he will not drop out of the presidential race.\n\nIn a mocking tone, Trump called Biden's choice of Harris, the first Black and woman vice president, his \"one brilliant decision,\" implying that she was so inept that Democrats were reluctant to replace Biden with her on the top of the ticket.\n\n\"It was an insurance policy, maybe the best insurance policy I've ever seen,\" Trump said. \"If Joe had picked someone even halfway competent, they would have bounced him from office years ago.\"\n\nTrump also accused Harris, a former U.S. Senator and California attorney general, of working with other Democrats on covering up Biden's alleged mental acuity issues. Biden has said he has the stamina and mental sharpness to do the job.\n\nTrump also said Harris's record would hurt her electoral chances, the latest sign that he and his Republican allies are starting an all-out assault on Harris to prepare for Biden possibly ending his re-election bid.\n\n\"I don't think Kamala Harris's California socialism is going to go down well with the people of Doral, the people of Miami or the people of Florida. Because in Florida we don't like socialism, we want our freedom,\" Trump said.\n\nThe Biden campaign accused Trump of lying about Harris, and said he was trying to deflect from growing attention paid to Project 2025, a conservative group's controversial plans to remake the presidency should Trump win the Nov. 5 election.\n\n\"Trump's bizarre and unhinged rants won't stop Vice President Harris from defending the Biden-Harris record and prosecuting the case against Donald Trump's extreme record,\" Biden campaign spokesperson Ammar Moussa said.\n\nGOLF CHALLENGE\n\nSeemingly joking, Trump challenged Biden to another debate, saying that it should be \"man to man, no moderators, no holds barred,\" and to 18 holes of golf - a reference to their argument during the debate over who was better at the sport.\n\n\"It will be among the most watched sporting events in history, maybe bigger than the Ryder Cup or even the Masters,\" Trump said, adding that he would give Biden 20 strokes.\n\nThe Biden campaign dismissed Trump's golf challenge as a stunt. They said Biden, who gave a speech at the NATO summit in Washington on Tuesday vowing to defend Ukraine against Russian President Vladimir Putin's invasion, was too busy governing.\n\n\"We'd challenge Donald Trump to stand up to Putin, but he bent the knee to him,\" said campaign spokesperson James Singer.\n\nTrump praised what he called an \"incredible decision\" by the Supreme Court last week determining that he could not be prosecuted for actions within his constitutional powers as president, a landmark decision that could have broad implications for the criminal charges he is facing.\n\nBiden called the ruling \"a dangerous precedent\" because the power of the presidency will no longer be constrained by law.\n\nCalling the prosecutions against him politically motivated, Trump said he had \"great respect for the courage\" shown by the conservative justices who ruled in his favor. \"They have great intellect and great insight, incredible insight,\" he said.\n\nOn Saturday, the former president will travel to Pennsylvania for an afternoon rally in Butler, just outside of Pittsburgh, where the focus will be on any hint - or announcement - about whom he will pick as vice president.\n\nRubio, Ohio Senator J.D. Vance and North Dakota Governor Doug Burgum are seen as the leading contenders to join Trump on the Republican ticket. Trump said this week that he would likely make a decision \"a little before\" or during the Republican Party's national convention, which kicks off on July 15.\n\nCalling out Rubio by name, Trump pointed out the large number of journalists in attendance. \"I think they probably think I'm going to be announcing that Marco is going to be vice president, because that's a lot of press,\" he said.\n\nMeanwhile, a growing number of Democrats in the Congress said they worried that President Joe Biden could not beat Donald Trump in the election, though they emerged from closed-door meetings on Tuesday with no plans for collective action.\n\nA seventh Democrat in the U.S. House of Representatives publicly called on the 81-year-old incumbent to end his wounded reelection campaign, and the first Senate Democrat came forward to say that Biden could not win, though he stopped short of calling on him to drop out.\n\n\"Donald Trump is on track, I think, to win this election and maybe win it by a landslide and take with it the Senate and the House,\" Democratic Senator Michael Bennet said in an interview on CNN. Asked if Biden should end his campaign, he replied, \"This is something for the president to consider.\"\n\nIf Trump wins the White House and Republicans win majorities in both chambers of Congress, he will face few obstacles in pursuit of major policy changes. Democrats already face an uphill battle to protect their 51-49 Senate majority, as they must defend multiple seats in Republican-leaning states.\n\nRepublicans hold a 220-213 majority in the House.\n\nThe party's leaders in the U.S. Senate and House, Chuck Schumer and Hakeem Jeffries, said little about hours of closed-door talks among Democratic lawmakers, who in any event lack the authority to push Biden aside even if they agreed on a course of action.\n\nBiden's halting June 27 debate performance against Trump and low public approval have raised fresh doubts among some Democrats about his ability to win or to keep up with the demands of his grueling job for another 4-1/2 years.\n\nRepresentative Mikie Sherrill became the seventh House Democrat to call on Biden publicly to drop out of the race, saying in a statement, \"The stakes are too high - and the threat is too real - to stay silent.\"\n\nMany more lawmakers have expressed worries that Biden has not done enough in the ensuing days to convince voters that the debate was an aberration, rather than a true reflection of his abilities.\n\nBut the president continues to argue that he is best positioned to defeat former President Trump, 78, whom he casts as a singular threat to American democracy.\n\nSenate Majority Leader Schumer brushed off questions about Biden's fitness, saying three times, \"I'm with Joe,\" during a brief exchange with reporters after Senate Democrats met over lunch to discuss the president's campaign.\n\n\"While President Biden has made clear he feels he is the best candidate to win this election, nothing that has happened over the past twelve days suggests that voters see things the same way,\" Representative Lori Trahan said in a statement on Tuesday.\n\nA Reuters/Ipsos poll last week found that one in three registered Democratic voters believed that Biden should quit the race, with 59% saying he is too old to work in government.\n\nThe poll also found that none of his possible replacements fared better in a matchup against Trump. The poll showed Biden and Trump tied at 40% each.\n\nSWING-STATE SHIFT\n\nWhile national public opinion polls offer a view of candidates' standing, U.S. presidential elections are decided state by state. The nonpartisan Cook Political Report on Tuesday changed its ratings on three of the most competitive states -- Arizona, Georgia and Nevada -- to \"lean Republican\" from \"toss-up,\" citing shifting voter views of Biden following the debate.\n\nBiden delivered a forceful speech to a gathering of NATO leaders in Washington on Tuesday, while Vice President Kamala Harris - seen as the most likely candidate to replace Biden if he were to stand down - campaigned in Nevada.\n\n\"The one thing we know about Joe Biden is he is a fighter. He is the first to say when you get knocked down, you get back up,\" Harris told supporters in Las Vegas.\n\nWhite House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre faced another salvo of questions from reporters about Biden's health on Tuesday. In a statement, the White House physician said Biden was not being treated for any neurological condition and had received a clean bill of health at his most recent physical examination in February.\n\nBiden has secured renewed support from several key constituencies, including from members of the Congressional Black Caucus. Black voters make up a crucial component of the party's base.\n\nSome House Democrats expressed frustration that the party was focused on Biden's shortcomings rather than unifying against Trump, who falsely claims that his 2020 loss was the result of fraud and has not committed to accepting this year's results if he loses.\n\n\"I think the president has decided that the discussion has come to an end and that he is firm in his commitment to run,\" Representative Stephen Lynch said of Biden, adding that the dissidents \"are gonna have to get on board.\"", "source": {"uri": "cyprus-mail.com", {"uri": "2024-07-416932770", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "04:36:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T04:36:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T04:16:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://arab.news/ngsdf", "title": "Trump revels in Democratic turmoil as he returns to campaign trail", "body": "Trump ratchets up his attacks on both Joe Biden and Kamala Harris after days spent lying low\n\nMIAMI: Former President Donald Trump on Tuesday reveled in the mounting turmoil surrounding President Joe Biden 's campaign in the wake of their debate and teased the expected announcement of his Republican running mate with one of the top contenders, Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, in attendance.\n\nAfter days spent lying low, golfing and letting Democratic infighting play out in public, Trump used his return to the campaign trail in Florida to ratchet up his attacks on both Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris, indulging speculation that she could replace the president as the Democratic nominee this year and alleging, without evidence, that his son Hunter Biden is \"running our government\" and first lady Jill Biden \"is helping.\" Biden has repeatedly insisted he won't withdraw from the race.\n\nTrump rallied his supporters at one of his Miami-area golf courses as the presumptive Republican nominee nears a deadline to announce his running mate. But he appears in no rush, as much of the political world's attention is still centered on questions about Biden's ability to govern for another four-year term. Some Democrats have started calling for Biden to step down as their presumptive nominee following his dismal debate performance last month.\n\nTrump, speaking from the 10th hole of his course, challenged Biden to another debate or even a \"golf-off\" reviving an offbeat argument from their debate. But mostly, he rubbed in how their meetup left Biden's campaign facing a grim prognosis.\n\n\"Our victory was so absolute that Joe's own party now wants him to throw in the towel and surrender the presidency after a single 90-minute performance,\" Trump said Tuesday night. \"They want 'Crooked Joe' out of the race. It's a shame the way they're treating him. But don't feel sorry for him. He's a very bad guy.\"\n\nJames Singer, a spokesperson for Biden's campaign, responded to Trump with a series of challenges, saying in a statement: \"We'd challenge Donald Trump to create jobs, but he lost 3 million. We'd challenge Donald Trump to stand up to Putin, but he bent the knee to him. We'd challenge Donald Trump to follow the law, but he breaks it.\"\n\nSinger also said, \"Joe Biden doesn't have time for Donald Trump's weird antics -- he's busy leading America and defending the free world.\"\n\nTrump laced into Harris with more specifics than usual. She has become a focus of the former president and his allies as speculation has mounted that she would replace Biden as the Democratic nominee. Trump called her \"Laughing Kamala,\" and referred to the \"Biden-Harris administration,\" rather than just pinning actions on Biden as he had for months, and blamed Harris for the White House's immigration policies.\n\n\"Despite all the Democrat panic this week, the truth is, it doesn't matter who they nominate because we are going to beat any one of them in thundering landslides and this November's going to be amazing,\" he said.\n\nTrump, ever the showman, repeatedly played into the speculation that he might elevate Rubio to his ticket.\n\nRubio, a Miami native and one of the contenders for the vice presidential post, was among the Florida politicians who spoke at the event.\n\nAt one point, Trump marveled at the number of reporters in attendance and said, \"I think they probably think I'm going to be announcing that Marco is going to be vice president.\"\n\nLater, when he talked about his pledge to make tips tax-free, he remarked that Rubio \"may or may not be there to vote for it.\"\n\nRubio, the son of Cuban immigrants, is seen as a potential running mate who could help Trump as he tries to secure support from Hispanic Americans, a point the senator emphasized in his remarks as he switched several times in his remarks to Spanish.\n\nThe senator did not openly acknowledge any of the speculation about him joining Trump as a running mate. He instead skewered not only Biden, whom he called \"the figurehead of a left-wing government, shadow government,\" but Harris, whom he would need to debate head-on if he's chosen for Trump's ticket.\n\nRubio referred to Harris not by name at first but called her Biden's \"replacement\" and \"a real-life, verified left-winger.\" At another point in his remarks, he mocked the way Harris laughs.\n\nHe notably seemed to insert himself into Trump's signature \"Make America Great Again\" slogan by saying: \"Together, we're not just going to make it great again. We elect this man as president, we will make together America greater than it has ever been.\"\n\nThousands of people turned out in the humid summer evening for the rally. Attendees were fanning themselves and holding signs featuring Trump's mug shot, along with others that said, \"You're fired!\" -- Trump's signature phrase on his former reality show, \"The Apprentice.\"\n\nTrump's youngest child who recently turned 18, Barron, also made his first-ever appearance at one of his father's rallies. Trump implored his son to stand, with the young man pumping his fist a few times as Trump said, \"Welcome to the scene, Barron.\"\n\nBoth Biden, 81, and Trump, 78, are at least two decades older than most American presidents have been, according to the Pew Research Center, which said the median age for all US presidents on their first inauguration is 55 years old.\n\nBut that has not stopped Trump from arguing he is stronger than Biden, who repeatedly stumbled, paused and could not complete sentences at times during the June 27 debate.", "source": {"uri": "arab.news", "dataType": "news",
