{"uri": "2024-07-416821587", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "01:07:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T01:07:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T00:31:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/trump-revels-in-democratic-turmoil-as-he-returns-to-campaign-trail-and-teases-vp-pick/article_ea3a5cb4-33c1-551b-9e65-bd6751b5fcf7.html", "title": "Trump revels in Democratic turmoil as he returns to campaign trail and teases VP pick", "body": "By ADRIANA GOMEZ LICON and MICHELLE L. PRICE - Associated Press\n\nMIAMI (AP) -- After largely ceding the spotlight to the mounting turmoil surrounding President Joe Biden 's campaign in the wake of their debate, former President Donald Trump returned to the campaign trail Tuesday and reveled in the Democratic infighting that has played out in public.\n\nTrump rallied his supporters at one of his Miami-area golf courses as he nears a deadline to announce his running mate. But he appears in no rush as much of the attention is still centered on questions about Biden's ability to govern for another four-year term. Some Democrats have started calling for Biden to step down as their presumptive nominee following his dismal debate performance last month.\n\n\"Our victory was so absolute that Joe's own party now wants him to throw in the towel and surrender the presidency after a single 90-minute performance,\" Trump said Tuesday night. \"They want 'Crooked Joe' out of the race. It's a shame the way they're treating him. But don't feel sorry for him. He's a very bad guy.\"\n\nTrump also laced into Vice President Kamala Harris, who has become a focus of the former president and his allies as speculation has mounted that she would replace Biden as the Democratic nominee. Trump called her \"Laughing Kamala,\" and referred to the \"Biden-Harris administration,\" rather than just pinning actions on Biden, as he had for months, as he criticized their immigration policies.\n\n\"Despite all the Democrat panic this week, the truth is, it doesn't matter who they nominate -- because we are going to beat any one of them in a thundering landslides and this November's going to be amazing,\" he said.\n\nBoth Biden, 81, and Trump, 78, are at least two decades older than most American presidents have been, according to the Pew Research Center, which said the median age for all U.S. presidents on their first inauguration is 55 years old. But that has not stopped Trump from arguing he is stronger than Biden, who repeatedly stumbled, paused and could not complete sentences at times during the June 27 debate. Trump was criticized by Democrats for making false statements during the debate about the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol and suggesting immigrants entering the U.S. illegally were taking so-called \"Black jobs\" and \"Hispanic jobs.\"\n\nIn an interview Monday with Fox News Channel's Sean Hannity, Trump said he thought Biden \"might very well stay in\" the race. \"Nobody to wants to give that up that way,\" Trump added. \"He is going to feel badly about himself for a long time. It's hard to give it up that way, the way where they're trying to force him out.\"\n\nIn the Miami suburb of Doral, Trump underscored his strong support in a former battleground state that has now shifted toward the GOP. U.S. Sen. Marco Rubio, a Miami native and one of the contenders for the vice presidential post, was among the Florida politicians who spoke at the event.\n\nRubio, the son of Cuban immigrants, is seen as a potential running mate who could help Trump as he tries to secure support from Hispanic Americans, a point the senator emphasized in his remarks as he switched several times in his remarks to Spanish.\n\nThe senator did not openly acknowledge any of the speculation about him joining Trump as a running mate. He instead skewered not only Biden, whom he called \"the figurehead of a left-wing government, shadow government,\" but Harris, whom he would need to debate head-on if he's chosen for Trump's ticket.\n\nRubio referred to Harris not by name at first but called her Biden's \"replacement\" and \"a real-life, verified left-winger.\" At another point in his remarks, he mocked the way Harris laughs.\n\nHe notably seemed to insert himself into Trump's signature \"Make America Great Again\" slogan by saying: \"Together, we're not just going to make it great again. We elect this man as president, we will make together America greater than it has ever been.\"\n\nThousands of people turned out in the humid summer evening for the rally. Attendees were fanning themselves and holding signs featuring Trump's mug shot, along with others that said, \"You're fired!\" -- Trump's signature phrase on his former reality show, \"The Apprentice.\"\n\nOne man, 28-year-old Austin Stiglin, said he traveled from northern Florida to participate in his first Trump rally. He was wearing a star-patterned navy blue jacket and red pants and said he was \"tired of the left telling him to vote left just because I am gay.\"\n\n\"I have a lot more to say than just my sexual orientation,\" Stiglin said. \"I would like to vote for policies that support the United States.\"\n\nNicole Farrell, a 57-year-old immigrant from Trinidad, said she voted for Trump in 2020, \"but I was not a strong supporter like now. I just preferred him over Biden.\"\n\nFarrell said she specifically likes Trump's hardline immigration policies, which include plans for mass raids and the largest deportation operation in U.S. history.\n\n\"I am an immigrant but I came here legally. They need to come here legally,\" Farrell said of migrants coming to the U.S.\n\nThe presumptive GOP nominee is expected in his remarks to touch on Biden's handling of immigration and the economy, highlighting the rise in home prices and goods. Trump will also talk about how Florida is affected by the increasing arrivals of immigrants as the final destination for many people illegally crossing the U.S.-Mexico border.\n\nThe leadership crisis among Democrats has perhaps given Trump a reason to wait for his VP announcement so as to not draw attention away from Biden's woes. Senior advisers and key allies say they still don't know whom Trump will choose as his running mate, and many believe the choice is still in flux.\n\nSpeaking on MSNBC Monday, Biden criticized Trump for not having held events since the debate and suggested he had been \"riding around in his golf cart.\"\n\nPrice reported from New York.\n\nMore from this section\n\nMocPOGO Pokemon GO Hacks Updated: Fixes Failed to Detect Location Error 12\n\nUnited Filmmakers Announces an Exciting Financing Opportunity for Independent Filmmakers\n\nDirect Mail Benchmark Report 2024 reveals 61% of marketers have increased direct mail investments in the last year", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KULR-8 Local News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@kulr8.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "michelle_l_price@kulr8.com", "name": "Michelle L. {"uri": "2024-07-417183631", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "09:08:08", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T09:08:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T08:50:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/us/key-criteria-for-vp-candidates-as-described-by-trumps-former-national-security-adviser/", "title": "Key Criteria for VP Candidates as Described by Trump's Former National Security Adviser - Internewscast Journal", "body": "Donald Trump's running mate will have to correctly answer two key questions if they want to find their name on the ticket, his former national security advisor revealed.\n\nAs speculation swirls around who the former president might select as his vice-president, John Bolton, who served under the ex-president between March 2018 and September 2019, revealed Trump's decision will hinge on just one decisive issue: the last election.\n\n'I'm afraid that the vice presidential interview questionnaire has only two questions on it,' Bolton told CNN's Kaitlan Collins, adding that Trump's 'highest priority is absolute personal loyalty to him.'\n\nHe said the first question would be: 'Do you think the 2020 election was stolen?'\n\nLeading on from the first, he speculated that Trump would then ask: 'If I told you to do what I told Mike Pence to do on January 6, would you do it?'\n\nBolton, who became a frequent Trump critic after leaving his White House, said the candidates on Trump's VP shortlist would need to answer yes to both questions to 'make it into the finals.'\n\n'And if they're a no, you're out of it,' he added.\n\nBolton felt that it would take a 'great loss of integrity' to fall in line behind Trump, and warned them that any early promises to be on the Republican ticket aren't to be trusted, because 'with Trump, it's never final until it's final.'\n\nIt came as Trump appeared to tease at a rally in Miami on Tuesday night that he could pick Florida Senator Marco Rubio, who has seemingly found himself in the final shortlist.\n\nTrump repeatedly name-dropped Rubio during his rally, as he said there has been a 'lot of press' around the former presidential candidate's prospects.\n\n'They'll probably be thinking that I'll be announcing Rubio as my vice president,' Trump even admitted at one stage.\n\nHe also prodded Rubio over his policy proposal to remove taxes from tips if he regains the White House, and told him that 'you may or may not be there to vote for it - but you'll be involved.'\n\nTrump's running mate roster is also believed to include Ohio Senator J.D. Vance and North Dakota Governor Doug Burgum, with outside names Vivek Ramaswamy and Byron Donalds also floated in recent months.\n\nIn recent days, a DailyMail.com poll found that South Carolina Senator Tim Scott led the pack at 13 percent support, with Rubio in second at 12 percent tied with former Trump cabinet member Ben Carson.\n\nTrump has frequently said he will announce his running mate at the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee next week, however Bolton said he may break from tradition and hold off because of the negative press cycle surrounding President Biden.\n\n'Look, there's no news coming out of the Republican National Convention, other than the vice presidential nomination,' Bolton concluded.\n\n'Why waste it in a week when the Democrats may still be talking about whether Joe Biden's competent to be president?'\n\nTrump used the occasion to introduce his son Barron to his adoring crowd, receiving raucous applause as he announced, 'Welcome to the scene, Barron.'\n\nThe former president joked that his son 'had such a nice, easy life - now it's a little bit changed,' and the 6-foot-9 teen was seen pumping his fist to the crowd in typical Trump fashion.\n\n'Where is Barron? Stand up. Look at him! You're pretty popular,' Trump said from the stage, where he was joined by a number of Republican figureheads including Florida Senator Rick Scott.\n\nTrump went on to issue several challenges to Biden, first saying he wants to debate the 81-year-old ahead of their next scheduled bout on September 10.\n\nHe then challenged Biden to a golf match and staked $1 million on the game, while offering to give the president a 20-shot handicap after they sparred over their golf games at the debate.\n\n'I'm also officially challenging Crooked Joe to an 18-hole golf match right here. On Doral's Blue Monster considered one of the greatest tournament golf courses anywhere in the world,' Trump said. 'It will be among the most-watched sporting events in history.\n\n'And if he wins I will give the charity of his choice - any charity that he wants - 10 million dollars,' the ex-president added. 'And I bet he doesn't take the offer.'\n\nThe Biden campaign quickly clapped back, calling Trump's rally 'deranged.'\n\n'Joe Biden doesn't have time for Donald Trump's weird antics - he's busy leading America and defending the free world,' said campaign spokesperson James Singer.\n\nSinger noted that Trump's rally consisted of the ex-president 'inviting fictional serial killers to dinner, teasing lil' Marco Rubio, praising Project 2025 architect Tom Homan, and challenging the President of the United States to golf.'\n\nAnalysts and pundits noted that Trump was unusually restrained following Biden's disastrous debate performance against him, which sparked furious speculation that Democrats could look to replace the 81-year-old before November's election.\n\nBiden's every move has come under scrutiny following the debate, and his speech to NATO leaders on Tuesday was his latest chance to dispel rumors he is too old for another four years in the White House.\n\nThe octogenarian president narrowly avoided a near disastrous slip-up during his welcome speech, although he read a three-word instruction to himself as he visibly read from a teleprompter.\n\nAs he awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom to NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg, Biden was seemingly saved from utter embarrassment by the audience applause, as he declared: 'Ask the military aide.'\n\nBiden then quickly caught himself, while the crowd drowned up the flub with cheers.\n\n'Military come forward,' he said. He proceeded to award the medal, hanging it around Stoltenberg's neck, without incident.\n\nWith a growing number of congressional Democrats calling for Biden to step aside, many pointed to Vice President Kamala Harris as his natural successor to take on Trump.\n\nWith speculation falling on Harris' potential candidacy, several Democrats have been named as potential running mates if she had to step up to the top of the ticket.\n\nAs the first black and Asian American female presidential nominee of a major party if Biden were to drop out, analysts believe she would need a running mate who looks like nearly all the former presidents to temper any shocks to identity politics.\n\nAmong the names being floated are Governors Roy Cooper of North Carolina, Andy Beshear of Kentucky and Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania, two people close to the Biden-Harris campaign told the New York Times.", "source": {"uri": "internewscast.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Internewscast Journal"}, {"uri": "8216900098", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "12:06:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T12:06:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T12:06:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.inquirer.com/politics/nation/former-president-donald-trump-vice-president-pick-election-20240709.html", "title": "Donald Trump's VP search comes down to its final days", "body": "NEW YORK -- The future Republican vice presidential candidate's plane is currently parked in an undisclosed hangar, an empty spot on its fuselage where a decal featuring his or her name will soon be placed.\n\n\" READ MORE: Here's a look at Donald Trump's vice-presidential short list, and why each contender may get picked or fall short\n\nSenior advisers and longtime allies insist they still don't know whom the presumptive GOP nominee will choose to join him on the ticket -- with many believing the name is still in flux.\n\n\"I haven't made (a) final decision. But I have some ideas as to where we're going,\" Trump said in an interview with Fox News Channel's Sean Hannity that aired Monday night.\n\nThe decision will come at an unprecedented time of upheaval in the presidential race. President Joe Biden and the Democratic Party continue to grapple with his dismal debate performance and the intensifying calls for the 81-year-old president to step aside in favor of a younger candidate.\n\nThe Democrats' crisis has given Trump little incentive to change the subject with a VP announcement that would be sure to draw a flurry of attention and focus.\n\n\" READ MORE: Panicked Pennsylvania Democrats launch into cleanup mode after Biden's bad debate night\n\nTrump has also been waiting to see how things shake out with Biden.\n\n\"A little bit, you know, we wanted to see what they're doing, to be honest. Because, you know, it might make a difference,\" he told Hannity.\n\nBut Trump will have plenty of opportunities this week to ratchet up the speculation about a process that his team has kept extraordinarily close to the vest.\n\n\"It could happen anytime this week,\" Trump senior adviser Jason Miller said in an appearance on \"Fox & Friends.\"\n\nTrump has two rallies planned. The first is scheduled for Tuesday evening at his golf club in Doral, Florida, near Miami. The primetime scheduling and location would seem to provide an ideal opportunity to unveil his pick if it is Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, a Miami native who is one of his top contenders.\n\nRubio will be in attendance at the event, according to an adviser familiar with the senator's plans, who, like others, spoke on condition of anonymity about the selection process.\n\n\" READ MORE: Trump's youth movement: Why some young voters in deep blue Philadelphia are backing the former president\n\nOn Saturday Trump will travel to the critical battleground state of Pennsylvania for another rally at the Butler Farm Show. The venue, outside Pittsburgh, is not far from the border of Ohio, which is home to Sen. JD Vance, another potential pick.\n\nAlso on Trump's short list is North Dakota Gov. Doug Burgum, who has grown close to the former president since he dropped his own bid for the nomination before voting began.\n\nTrump doesn't need a rally to unveil his pick. He could simply announce the news on his Truth Social platform at any moment between now and the Republican National Convention, which kicks off in Milwaukee on July 15. Or he could wait until the convention opens to make a grand, onstage curtain reveal reminiscent of his days as the host of the \"The Apprentice\" reality TV show.\n\nHe said Monday the announcement will come \"probably a little before the convention, but not much. It could even be during the convention that we'd do it. I'd love to do it during the convention. ... It would make it even more exciting.\"\n\n\" READ MORE: Trump rallies in North Philly as he tries to win over voters in Pennsylvania's bluest big city\n\nTrump has spent months now teasing his choice.\n\nLate last month, before the debate, Trump told NBC News at a campaign stop in Philadelphia that he'd already made a decision.\n\n\"In my mind, yeah,\" he said.\n\nBut less than a week later, he told a local Virginia television station that his decision was still in flux.\n\n\"Well I have people in mind. I have so many good people. We have such a deep bench,\" he said. \"But we'll be making a decision sometime early convention or before convention.\"\n\n\"(A)nyone telling you they know who or when President Trump will choose his VP is lying unless that person is named Donald J. Trump,\" Trump adviser Brian Hughes said in a statement he has issued repeatedly.\n\nThat includes the front-runners for the job.\n\nOn CNN's \"State of the Union\" on Sunday, Rubio said he remained in the dark.\n\n\"Look, I've heard nothing, I know nothing, and you probably know more than I do about it,\" he said. \"Donald Trump has a decision to make. He'll make it when he needs to make it. He'll make a good decision. I know for certain that I will be out there over the next three or four months, working on behalf of his campaign in some capacity.\"\n\n\" READ MORE: Concern about Biden's age, Trump's struggle to respond to criminal conviction, and other highlights from the first debate\n\nHe also dismissed questions about whether he has discussed changing his residence from Florida if he's chosen as \"presumptuous.\" The Constitution bars the president and vice president from hailing from the same state.\n\n\"We'll confront those issues when they come,\" he said. \"But we're not there yet. But we will be soon, one way or the other.\"\n\nOn NBC's \"Meet the Press,\" Vance, too, said he has not received news one way or the other: \"I have not gotten the call.\"\n\n\"But most importantly,\" he went on, \"we're just trying to work to elect Donald Trump. Whoever his vice president is -- he's got a lot of good people he could choose from -- it's the policies that worked and the leadership style that worked for the American people.\"\n\n\" READ MORE: Trump's surrogates reached out to Black voters in Philly with cigars and cognac\n\nOn CBS's \"Face the Nation,\" Sen. Lindsey Graham, a longtime Trump ally, continued to push for his fellow South Carolinian, Sen. Tim Scott, the only Black Republican in the Senate.\n\n\"I don't think he's decided,\" he said, adding that Scott would be a particularly smart choice if Biden were to be replaced at the top of the ticket by Vice President Kamala Harris, the first Black woman and person of South Asian descent to serve in the office.\n\n\"If I were President Trump, I would make sure I pick somebody that could add value in 2024. {"uri": "8217876831", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "02:16:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T02:16:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T02:16:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://deadline.com/2024/07/trump-challenges-biden-debate-gold-match-1236005576/", "title": "Trump Challenges Biden Again To \"No Holds Barred\" Debate This Week, Tosses In Golf Match Too", "body": "For the second time in less than a week, Donald Trump has called on Joe Biden to go \"man-to-man\" in another debate, but this time the ex-president has thrown in a round or two of gold as well.\n\nSwinging at one topic after another at a Florida rally Tuesday, Trump challenged the incumbent \"the chance to redeem himself in front of the entire world\" after Biden's painful to watch June 27 debate spectacle live on CNN on June 27.\n\n\"Let's do another debate this week so that sleepy Joe Biden can prove to everyone all over the world that he has what it takes to be president,\" declared Trump to his MAGA base in the Sunshine State, teasing Sen. Marco Rubio as a potential VP pick. \"But this time it will be man-to-man, no moderators, no holds barred,\" Trump added, sounding a lot like his factitious invite of July 5.\n\n\"Just name the place, anytime, anywhere.\"\n\nStill fighting a war on many fronts to retain both his party and the public's faith that he is the man to beat Trump and complete another term, the 81-year-old Biden had one of his best days in over a week on Tuesday. Delivering some domestic and, with a strong speech at the NATO Summit in DC, international realpolitik, the self-declared \"running the world\" POTUS ended Tuesday in a more robust position that he went into the day.\n\nHowever, if Donald Trump thought the Biden campaign was going to treat his offer \"officially challenging crooked Joe to an 18-hole golf match\" on live TV on one of his own courses with anything more than contempt, he was sadly mistaken. Maybe he was right that the game between the rivals \"will be among the most watched sporting events in history, maybe bigger than the Ryder Cup or even the Masters,\" but otherwise the Biden team weren't playing around.\n\n\"Donald Trump hasn't been seen in public for 12 days, now he's inviting fictional serial killers to dinner, teasing lil' Marco Rubio, praising Project 2025 architect Tom Homan, and challenging the President of the United States to golf,\" said Biden-Harris 2024 spokesperson James Singer in a statement this evening.\n\nThen the still reeling reelection campaign tried to turn the tables on their 2020 and now 2024 rival just days before the GOP convention opens in Milwaukee, a town 78-year-old Trump reportedly called \"horrible\" to some fellow Republicans last month.\n\n\"We'd challenge Donald Trump to create jobs, but he lost 3 million,\" said the Biden-Harris team. \"We'd challenge Donald Trump to stand up to Putin, but he bent the knee to him. We'd challenge Donald Trump to follow the law, but he breaks it. We'd challenge Donald Trump to not destroy our country, but that's all his Project 2025 aims to do.\"\n\n\"Joe Biden doesn't have time for Donald Trump's weird antics - he's busy leading America and defending the free world,\" Singer concluded. \"Donald Trump is a liar, a convict, and a fraud only out for himself - par for the course.\"\n\nOf course, it was Biden who got into trash talk with Trump over golf in the train wreck June 27 face-off. In one of the few direct exchanges of the night between the two, and one of the few times that night that Biden seemed engaged, the current POTUS challenged the rather bloated former POTUS to a golf game \"if you (Trump) carry your own bag.\" Trump responded by calling Biden's boosts about his handicap \"a lie.\" Embaressing everyone, including moderators Dana Bash and Jake Tapper, the back and forth ended even more schoolyard than before with Trump stating \"let's not act like children,\" and Biden reacting \"you are a child.\"\n\nYep, that's the two senior citizens running for to be the most powerful person on Earth.\n\nIn terms of real debates, Trump and Biden are set to meet up again on ABC on September 10 at 9 pm ET - which is eons away in political terms.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8216783677", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "10:56:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T10:56:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T10:55:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.huffpost.com/entry/donald-trump-running-mate-2024-search_n_668d14f5e4b0a62057b83fe7", "title": "Trump's Running Mate Search Comes Down To Its Final Days", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- The future Republican vice presidential candidate's plane is currently parked in an undisclosed hangar, an empty spot on its fuselage where a decal featuring his or her name will soon be placed.\n\nSenior advisers and longtime allies insist they still don't know whom the presumptive GOP nominee will choose to join him on the ticket -- with many believing the name is still in flux.\n\n\"I haven't made (a) final decision. But I have some ideas as to where we're going,\" Trump said in an interview with Fox News Channel's Sean Hannity that aired Monday night.\n\nThe decision will come at an unprecedented time of upheaval in the presidential race. President Joe Biden and the Democratic Party continue to grapple with his dismal debate performance and the intensifying calls for the 81-year-old president to step aside in favor of a younger candidate.\n\nThe Democrats' crisis has given Trump little incentive to change the subject with a VP announcement that would be sure to draw a flurry of attention and focus.\n\nTrump has also been waiting to see how things shake out with Biden.\n\n\"A little bit, you know, we wanted to see what they're doing, to be honest. Because, you know, it might make a difference,\" he told Hannity.\n\nOpportunities to announce\n\nBut Trump will have plenty of opportunities this week to ratchet up the speculation about a process that his team has kept extraordinarily close to the vest.\n\n\"It could happen anytime this week,\" Trump senior adviser Jason Miller said in an appearance on \"Fox & Friends.\"\n\nTrump has two rallies planned. The first is scheduled for Tuesday evening at his golf club in Doral, Florida, near Miami. The primetime scheduling and location would seem to provide an ideal opportunity to unveil his pick if it is Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, a Miami native who is one of his top contenders.\n\nRubio will be in attendance at the event, according to an adviser familiar with the senator's plans, who, like others, spoke on condition of anonymity about the selection process.\n\nOn Saturday Trump will travel to the critical battleground state of Pennsylvania for another rally at the Butler Farm Show. The venue, outside Pittsburgh, is not far from the border of Ohio, which is home to Sen. JD Vance, another potential pick.\n\nAlso on Trump's short list is North Dakota Gov. Doug Burgum, who has grown close to the former president since he dropped his own bid for the nomination before voting began.\n\nTrump doesn't need a rally to unveil his pick. He could simply announce the news on his Truth Social platform at any moment between now and the Republican National Convention, which kicks off in Milwaukee on July 15. Or he could wait until the convention opens to make a grand, onstage curtain reveal reminiscent of his days as the host of the \"The Apprentice\" reality TV show.\n\nHe said Monday the announcement will come \"probably a little before the convention, but not much. It could even be during the convention that we'd do it. I'd love to do it during the convention. ... It would make it even more exciting.\"\n\nTrump has spent months now teasing his choice.\n\nLate last month, before the debate, Trump told NBC News at a campaign stop in Philadelphia that he'd already made a decision.\n\n\"In my mind, yeah,\" he said.\n\nBut less than a week later, he told a local Virginia television station that his decision was still in flux.\n\n\"Well I have people in mind. I have so many good people. We have such a deep bench,\" he said. \"But we'll be making a decision sometime early convention or before convention.\"\n\nThe front-runners say they don't know yet\n\n''(A)nyone telling you they know who or when President Trump will choose his VP is lying unless that person is named Donald J. Trump,\" Trump adviser Brian Hughes said in a statement he has issued repeatedly.\n\nThat includes the front-runners for the job.\n\nOn CNN's \"State of the Union\" on Sunday, Rubio said he remained in the dark.\n\n\"Look, I've heard nothing, I know nothing, and you probably know more than I do about it,\" he said. \"Donald Trump has a decision to make. He'll make it when he needs to make it. He'll make a good decision. I know for certain that I will be out there over the next three or four months, working on behalf of his campaign in some capacity.\"\n\nHe also dismissed questions about whether he has discussed changing his residence from Florida if he's chosen as \"presumptuous.\" The Constitution bars the president and vice president from hailing from the same state.\n\n\"We'll confront those issues when they come,\" he said. \"But we're not there yet. But we will be soon, one way or the other.\"\n\nOn NBC's \"Meet the Press,\" Vance, too, said he has not received news one way or the other: \"I have not gotten the call.\"\n\n\"But most importantly,\" he went on, \"we're just trying to work to elect Donald Trump. Whoever his vice president is -- he's got a lot of good people he could choose from -- it's the policies that worked and the leadership style that worked for the American people.\"\n\nA top ally is still pushing for Tim Scott\n\nOn CBS's \"Face the Nation,\" Sen. Lindsey Graham, a longtime Trump ally, continued to push for his fellow South Carolinian, Sen. Tim Scott, the only Black Republican in the Senate.\n\n\"I don't think he's decided,\" he said, adding that Scott would be a particularly smart choice if Biden were to be replaced at the top of the ticket by Vice President Kamala Harris, the first Black woman and person of South Asian descent to serve in the office.\n\n\"If I were President Trump, I would make sure I pick somebody that could add value in 2024. Expand the map,\" he said.\n\nBiden has insisted he won't drop out and said only \" the Lord Almighty \" could get him to change his mind.", "source": {"uri": "huffpost.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8217787101", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "00:15:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T00:15:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T00:14:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://macaudailytimes.com.mo/trump-returns-to-campaign-trail-amid-calls-for-biden-to-withdraw.html", "title": "Trump returns to campaign trail amid calls for Biden to withdraw | MACAU DAILY TIMES \u6fb3\u9580\u6bcf\u65e5\u6642\u5831", "body": "Republican presidential candidate former President Donald Trump speaks at a campaign rally, June 22, 2024, at Temple University in Philadelphia\n\nPresident Donald Trump is getting back on the campaign trail, rallying voters in his home state at his flagship golf resort in a celebratory mood as Democrats face tough calls over President Joe Biden's reelection chances.\n\nTrump is nearing a deadline to announce his running mate but appears in no rush as much of the attention is still centered on questions about Biden's ability to govern for another four-year term. Some Democrats have started calling for Biden to step down as their presumptive nominee following his dismal debate performance last month.\n\nBoth Biden, 81, and Trump, 78, are at least two decades older than most American presidents have been, according to the Pew Research Center, which said the median age for all U.S. presidents on their first inauguration is 55 years old. But that has not stopped Trump from arguing he is stronger than Biden, who repeatedly stumbled, paused and could not complete sentences at times during the June 27 debate. Trump was criticized by Democrats for making false statements during the debate about the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol and suggesting immigrants entering the U.S. illegally were taking so-called \"Black jobs\" and \"Hispanic jobs.\"\n\nIn an interview Monday with Fox News Channel's Sean Hannity, Trump said he thought Biden \"might very well stay in\" the race. \"Nobody to wants to give that up that way,\" Trump added. \"He is going to feel badly about himself for a long time. It's hard to give it up that way, the way where they're trying to force him out.\"\n\nIn the Miami suburb of Doral, Trump will underscore his strong support in a former battleground state that has now shifted toward the GOP. U.S. Sen. Marco Rubio, a Miami native and one of the contenders for the vice presidential post, will be attending the rally along with other Florida politicians.\n\nKevin Cabrera, a Miami-Dade County commissioner who was Florida state director for Trump's 2020 reelection campaign and is set to speak at the rally, said to expect an \"overwhelming show of unity.\"\n\n\"The rally will display our unified front, showcasing a stark contrast to the Democrats, who are lost and fighting with each other over Biden's health and ability to continue,\" Cabrera said.\n\nThe presumptive GOP nominee will also touch on Biden's handling of immigration and the economy, highlighting the rise in home prices and goods. Trump will also talk about how Florida is affected by the increasing arrivals of immigrants as the final destination for many people illegally crossing the U.S.-Mexico border.\n\nThe leadership crisis among Democrats has perhaps given Trump a reason to wait for his VP announcement so as to not draw attention away from Biden's woes. {"uri": "2024-07-417024744", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "06:39:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T06:39:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T06:08:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/trump-challenges-biden-to-another-debate-this-week-and-throws-in-a-golf-match-as-well/", "title": "Trump challenges Biden to another debate this week and throws in a golf match as well - Internewscast Journal", "body": "For the second time in less than a week, Donald Trump has called on Joe Biden to go \"man-to-man\" in another debate with no moderators, but this time the ex-president has thrown in a round or two of golf as well.\n\nSwinging at one topic after another, including the fictional Hannibal Lector again, at a Florida rally Tuesday, Trump challenged the incumbent \"the chance to redeem himself in front of the entire world\" after Biden's painful to watch June 27 debate spectacle live on CNN.\n\n\"Let's do another debate this week so that sleepy Joe Biden can prove to everyone all over the world that he has what it takes to be president,\" declared Trump to his MAGA base in the Sunshine State, dangling out Sen. Marco Rubio as a potential VP pick. \"But this time it will be man-to-man, no moderators, no holds barred,\" Trump added, sounding a lot like his factitious invite of July 5.\n\n\"Just name the place, anytime, anywhere.\"\n\nStill fighting a war on many fronts to retain both his party and the public's faith that he is the man to beat Trump and complete another term, the 81-year-old Biden had one of his best days in over a week on Tuesday. Delivering some domestic and, with a strong speech at the NATO Summit in DC, international realpolitik, the self-declared \"running the world\" POTUS ended Tuesday in a more robust position that he went into the day.\n\nHowever, if Donald Trump thought the Biden campaign was going to treat his offer \"officially challenging crooked Joe to an 18-hole golf match\" on live TV on one of his own courses with anything more than contempt, he was sadly mistaken. Now, maybe Trump was right that the game between the rivals \"will be among the most watched sporting events in history, maybe bigger than the Ryder Cup or even the Masters,\" but otherwise the Biden team weren't playing around.\n\n\"Donald Trump hasn't been seen in public for 12 days, now he's inviting fictional serial killers to dinner, teasing lil' Marco Rubio, praising Project 2025 architect Tom Homan, and challenging the President of the United States to golf,\" said Biden-Harris 2024 spokesperson James Singer in a statement this evening about the \"deranged rally,\" as the campaign termed it on social media.\n\nThen the still reeling reelection campaign tried to turn the tables on their 2020 and now 2024 rival just days before the GOP convention opens in Milwaukee, a town 78-year-old Trump reportedly called \"horrible\" to some fellow Republicans last month.\n\n\"We'd challenge Donald Trump to create jobs, but he lost 3 million,\" said the Biden-Harris team. \"We'd challenge Donald Trump to stand up to Putin, but he bent the knee to him. We'd challenge Donald Trump to follow the law, but he breaks it. We'd challenge Donald Trump to not destroy our country, but that's all his Project 2025 aims to do.\"\n\n\"Joe Biden doesn't have time for Donald Trump's weird antics - he's busy leading America and defending the free world,\" Singer concluded. \"Donald Trump is a liar, a convict, and a fraud only out for himself - par for the course.\"\n\nOf course, it was Biden who got into trash talk with Trump over golf in the train wreck June 27 face-off. In one of the few direct exchanges of the night between the two, and one of the few times that night that Biden seemed engaged, the current POTUS challenged the rather bloated former POTUS to a golf game \"if you (Trump) carry your own bag.\" Trump responded by calling Biden's boosts about his handicap \"a lie.\" Embarrassing everyone on-stage, including moderators Dana Bash and Jake Tapper, the back and forth ended even more schoolyard than before with Trump stating \"let's not act like children,\" and Biden reacting \"you are a child.\"\n\nYep, that's the two senior citizens running for to be the most powerful person on Earth.\n\nIn terms of real debates, Trump and Biden are set to meet up again on ABC on September 10 at 9 pm ET - which is eons away in political terms.", "source": Some Democrats have started calling for Biden to step down as their presumptive nominee following his dismal debate performance last month.Both Biden, 81, and Trump, 78, are at least two decades older than most American presidents have been, according to the Pew Research Center, which said the median age for all U.S. presidents on their first inauguration is 55 years old. But that has not stopped Trump from arguing he is stronger than Biden, who repeatedly stumbled, paused and could not complete sentences at times during the June 27 debate. Trump was criticized by Democrats for making false statements during the debate about the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol and suggesting immigrants entering the U.S. illegally were taking so-called \"Black jobs\" and \"Hispanic jobs.\"In an interview Monday with Fox News Channel's Sean Hannity, Trump said he thought Biden \"might very well stay in\" the race. \"Nobody to wants to give that up that way,\" Trump added. \"He is going to feel badly about himself for a long time. It's hard to give it up that way, the way where they're trying to force him out.\"In the Miami suburb of Doral, Trump will underscore his strong support in a former battleground state that has now shifted toward the GOP. U.S. Sen. Marco Rubio, a Miami native and one of the contenders for the vice presidential post, will be attending the rally along with other Florida politicians.Kevin Cabrera, a Miami-Dade County commissioner who was Florida state director for Trump's 2020 reelection campaign and is set to speak at the rally, said to expect an \"overwhelming show of unity.\"\"The rally will display our unified front, showcasing a stark contrast to the Democrats, who are lost and fighting with each other over Biden's health and ability to continue,\" Cabrera said.The presumptive GOP nominee will also touch on Biden's handling of immigration and the economy, highlighting the rise in home prices and goods. Trump will also talk about how Florida is affected by the increasing arrivals of immigrants as the final destination for many people illegally crossing the U.S.-Mexico border.The leadership crisis among Democrats has perhaps given Trump a reason to wait for his VP announcement so as to not draw attention away from Biden's woes. Senior advisers and key allies say they still don't know whom Trump will choose as his running mate, and many believe the choice is still in flux.Speaking on MSNBC Monday, Biden criticized Trump for not having held events since the debate and suggested he had been \"riding around in his golf cart.\"\n\nFormer President Donald Trump is getting back on the campaign trail Tuesday, rallying voters in his home state at his flagship golf resort in a celebratory mood as Democrats face tough calls over President Joe Biden's reelection chances.\n\nTrump is nearing a deadline to announce his running mate but appears in no rush as much of the attention is still centered on questions about Biden's ability to govern for another four-year term. Some Democrats have started calling for Biden to step down as their presumptive nominee following his dismal debate performance last month.\n\nBoth Biden, 81, and Trump, 78, are at least two decades older than most American presidents have been, according to the Pew Research Center, which said the median age for all U.S. presidents on their first inauguration is 55 years old. But that has not stopped Trump from arguing he is stronger than Biden, who repeatedly stumbled, paused and could not complete sentences at times during the June 27 debate. It's hard to give it up that way, the way where they're trying to force him out.\"\n\nIn the Miami suburb of Doral, Trump will underscore his strong support in a former battleground state that has now shifted toward the GOP. Trump will also talk about how Florida is affected by the increasing arrivals of immigrants as the final destination for many people illegally crossing the U.S.-Mexico border.\n\nThe leadership crisis among Democrats has perhaps given Trump a reason to wait for his VP announcement so as to not draw attention away from Biden's woes. {"uri": "2024-07-416179382", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "11:55:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T11:55:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T11:33:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/news/donald-trump-expected-break-post-110014357.html", "title": "Donald Trump expected to break post-debate silence at Florida rally", "body": "Donald Trump expected to break post-debate silence at Florida rally\n\nRichard Luscombe in Miami\n\n9 July 2024 at 1:33 pm\n\nDonald Trump will host a rally in the Miami suburb of Doral on Tuesday night and break a relative - and uncharacteristic - silence over the turbulent aftermath of June's presidential debate that raised questions about Joe Biden's candidacy.\n\nA Trump campaign source and some political opponents say the former president's strategy has been to sit back and let Democrats tear into each other following Biden's dismal debate performance, intensifying calls for him to drop out of November's general election.\n\n\"We're trying something new and shutting up,\" an anonymous campaign insider told ABC News last week, a position effectively confirmed by Trump's decision to largely avoid public appearances since a prearranged rally in Virginia the day after the 27 June debate - and to limit his posts on his Truth Social platform.\n\nRelated: The Democrats who have called on Joe Biden to step down\n\nThough Trump did appear on Monday on Fox News to rail about immigrants and crime, despite the FBI reporting a major drop in violence in the first months of the year, the former Republican congressman Steve Stivers told the Hill: \"When your opponent is blowing himself up, don't interrupt. There's no reason to insert yourself in that conversation.\"\n\nIn Florida on Tuesday night, before a loyal crowd at the Doral golf club he owns, and in the first of two rallies he is staging this week, the presumptive Republican nominee is expected to revert to his usually voluble self - at least if messaging from inside his campaign is a guide.\n\nTrump's media office did not respond to a question from the Guardian seeking confirmation that the campaign was deliberately avoiding talking much about Biden's shaky debate performance. But in a statement, Trump acolytes attacked the president's \"flailing candidacy\" and urged him to stay in the race.\n\n\"Please keep doing these interviews,\" said Jake Schneider, rapid response director for the Republican National Committee (RNC), referring to Biden calling into MSNBC's Morning Joe on Monday and insisting \"I am not going anywhere.\"\n\nOnly in Biden's mind, the statement said, \"is his defiance helping his case as a steady drip of Democrats call for a change at the top of their ticket\".\n\nSome senior Democrats also have thoughts on the former president's silence, including David Axelrod, a senior adviser for the Obama White House, whose relationship with Biden has been fractious.\n\n\"Trump's not talking much about Biden's bad debate. Trump's campaign is not blitzing ads about it. And Lara Trump [RNC co-chair and Trump's daughter-in-law] said last week it would be an affront to democracy if Biden were not the nominee,\" he wrote Monday on X.\n\n\"Why do you think they are uncharacteristically holding fire?\"\n\nIt is also possible that Trump is more concerned about advancing his own campaign, notably who to choose as his running mate one week before the Republican national convention in Milwaukee will confirm his third run at the White House as a Republican candidate.\n\nAmong those who will attend Tuesday's rally is Marco Rubio, a senior Florida US senator, believed to be one of the leading contenders for Trump's vice-presidential pick. A failed challenger to Trump for the Republican presidential nomination in 2016, when Mike Pence emerged as Trump's running mate, Rubio said on CNN on Sunday that he had \"heard nothing\".\n\n\"Donald Trump has a decision to make. He'll make it when he needs to make it. He'll make a good decision,\" he said.\n\nSpeculation has grown that the Doral event will provide Trump the perfect opportunity to unveil Rubio, particularly as Jason Miller, a senior Trump adviser, told Fox News on Monday that a decision was imminent.\n\nTrump will also rally Saturday at Pittsburgh's Butler Farm Show, close to Pennsylvania's border with Ohio, where JD Vance - another understood to be on the shortlist - is a senator.\n\nVance, on NBC's Meet the Press on Sunday, also attempted to dampen expectations. \"I have not gotten the call,\" he said.\n\n\"Whoever his vice-president is, he's got a lot of good people he could choose from, it's the policies that worked and the leadership style that worked for the American people.\"\n\nMiller's comments, meanwhile, hinted that Trump might also choose to wait to see if Biden drops out before declaring his hand.\n\n\"I look ahead as a campaign strategist to what does that vice-presidential debate look like,\" he said, citing the hypothesis that Kamala Harris, Biden's vice-president, would replace him at the top of the ticket.\n\n\"We don't know if that's going to be Kamala, or maybe they swap her out for someone who's even more liberal, more extreme, although that might be tough to do.\"\n\nThe Trump campaign's announcement of the Doral rally, meanwhile, gave little indication of what he will talk about, other than how the Biden administration was \"having catastrophic consequences on Floridians\", economically and in terms of immigration.\n\n\"Florida is a place near and dear to president Trump's heart as his home state,\" it said, referring to his Mar-a-Lago mansion in Palm Beach.\n\nTrump holds a solid 10-point advantage over Biden in Florida, according to fivethirtyeight.com's average of polls.", "source": {"uri": "2024-07-417405018", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:13:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:13:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T11:30:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://roanoke.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/trump-vp-announcement-rubio-vance-burgum/article_37480e94-e047-547d-9360-30fc1c3a04a4.html", "title": "The plane is ready, the fundraisers are booked: Trump's VP search comes down to its final days", "body": "NEW YORK -- The future Republican vice presidential candidate's plane is currently parked in an undisclosed hangar, an empty spot on its fuselage where a decal featuring his or her name will soon be placed.\n\nFundraisers have been planned.\n\nAll that's left: an announcement from former President Donald Trump unveiling his pick.\n\nSenior advisers and longtime allies insist they still don't know whom the presumptive GOP nominee will choose to join him on the ticket -- with many believing the choice is still in flux.\n\n\"I haven't made (a) final decision. But I have some ideas as to where we're going,\" Trump said in an interview with Fox News Channel's Sean Hannity that aired Monday night.\n\nThe decision will come at an unprecedented time of upheaval in the presidential race. President Joe Biden and the Democratic Party continue to grapple with his dismal debate performance and the intensifying calls for the 81-year-old president to step aside in favor of a younger candidate.\n\nThe Democrats' crisis has given Trump little incentive to change the subject with a VP announcement that would be sure to draw a flurry of attention and focus.\n\nTrump has also been waiting to see how things shake out with Biden.\n\n\"A little bit, you know, we wanted to see what they're doing, to be honest. Because, you know, it might make a difference,\" he told Hannity.\n\nBut Trump will have plenty of opportunities this week to ratchet up the speculation about a process that his team has kept extraordinarily close to the vest.\n\n\"It could happen anytime this week,\" Trump senior adviser Jason Miller said in an appearance on Fox News.\n\nTrump has two rallies planned. The first is scheduled for Tuesday evening at his golf club in Doral, Florida, near Miami. The primetime scheduling and location would seem to provide an ideal opportunity to unveil his pick if it is Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, a Miami native who is one of his top contenders.\n\nRubio will be in attendance at the event, according to an adviser familiar with the senator's plans, who, like others, spoke on condition of anonymity about the selection process.\n\nOn Saturday Trump will travel to the critical battleground state of Pennsylvania for an afternoon rally at the Butler Farm Show. The venue, outside of Pittsburgh, is not far from the border of Ohio, which is home to Sen. JD Vance, another potential pick.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nAlso said to be on Trump's short list is North Dakota Gov. Doug Burgum, who has grown close to the former president since he dropped his own bid for the nomination before voting began.\n\nTrump doesn't need a rally to unveil his pick. He could simply announce the news on his Truth Social platform at any moment between now and the Republican National Convention, which kicks off in Milwaukee on July 15. Or he could wait until the convention opens to make a grand, on-stage curtain reveal reminiscent of his days as the host of the \"The Apprentice\" reality TV show.\n\nHe said Monday the announcement will come \"probably a little before the convention, but not much. It could even be during the convention that we'd do it. I'd love to do it during the convention. ... It would make it even more exciting.\"\n\nTrump has repeatedly said he intends to unveil his pick just before or during the convention. But he has been coy about his choice.\n\nLate last month, before the debate, Trump told NBC News at a campaign stop in Philadelphia that he'd already made a decision.\n\n\"In my mind, yeah,\" he said.\n\nBut less than a week later, he told a local Virginia television station that his decision was still in flux.\n\n\"Well I have people in mind. I have so many good people. We have such a deep bench,\" he said. \"But we'll be making a decision sometime early convention or before convention.\"\n\n\"As President Trump has said himself, the top criteria in selecting a Vice President is a strong leader who could make a great President,\" Trump adviser Brian Hughes said in a statement he has issued repeatedly. \"But anyone telling you they know who or when President Trump will choose his VP is lying unless that person is named Donald J. Trump.\"\n\nThat includes the front-runners for the job.\n\nOn CNN's \"State of the Union\" on Sunday, Rubio said he remained in the dark.\n\n\"Look, I've heard nothing, I know nothing, and you probably know more than I do about it,\" he said. \"Donald Trump has a decision to make. He'll make it when he needs to make it. He'll make a good decision. I know for certain that I will be out there over the next three or four months, working on behalf of his campaign in some capacity.\"\n\nHe also dismissed questions about whether he has discussed changing his residence from Florida if he's chosen as \"presumptuous.\" The Constitution bars the president and vice president from hailing from the same state.\n\n\"We'll confront those issues when they come,\" he said. \"But we're not there yet. But we will be soon, one way or the other.\"\n\nOn NBC's \"Meet the Press,\" Vance, too, said he has not received news one way or the other: \"I have not gotten the call.\"\n\n\"But most importantly,\" he went on, \"we're just trying to work to elect Donald Trump. Whoever his vice president is -- he's got a lot of good people he could choose from -- it's the policies that worked and the leadership style that worked for the American people. I think we have to bring that back to the White House, and I'm fighting to try to do that.\"\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up!\n\n* I understand and agree {"uri": "2024-07-416778057", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "23:26:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T23:26:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T23:00:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/trump-returns-to-campaigning-as-deadline-to-name-running-mate-nears-biden-rejects-calls-to/article_ea3a5cb4-33c1-551b-9e65-bd6751b5fcf7.html", "title": "Trump returns to campaigning as deadline to name running mate nears, Biden rejects calls to withdraw", "body": "By ADRIANA GOMEZ LICON and MICHELLE L. PRICE - Associated Press\n\nMIAMI (AP) -- After largely ceding the spotlight to the mounting turmoil surrounding President Joe Biden 's campaign in the wake of their debate, former President Donald Trump returns to the campaign trail Tuesday after days of laying low, golfing and letting Democratic infighting play out in public.\n\nTrump is set to rally his voters at one of his Miami-area golf courses as he nears a deadline to announce his running mate. But he appears in no rush as much of the attention is still centered on questions about Biden's ability to govern for another four-year term. Some Democrats have started calling for Biden to step down as their presumptive nominee following his dismal debate performance last month.\n\nBoth Biden, 81, and Trump, 78, are at least two decades older than most American presidents have been, according to the Pew Research Center, which said the median age for all U.S. presidents on their first inauguration is 55 years old. But that has not stopped Trump from arguing he is stronger than Biden, who repeatedly stumbled, paused and could not complete sentences at times during the June 27 debate. Trump was criticized by Democrats for making false statements during the debate about the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol and suggesting immigrants entering the U.S. illegally were taking so-called \"Black jobs\" and \"Hispanic jobs.\"\n\nIn an interview Monday with Fox News Channel's Sean Hannity, Trump said he thought Biden \"might very well stay in\" the race. \"Nobody to wants to give that up that way,\" Trump added. \"He is going to feel badly about himself for a long time. It's hard to give it up that way, the way where they're trying to force him out.\"\n\nIn the Miami suburb of Doral, Trump is expected to underscore his strong support in a former battleground state that has now shifted toward the GOP. U.S. Sen. Marco Rubio, a Miami native and one of the contenders for the vice presidential post, was among the Florida politicians who spoke at the event.\n\nRubio, the son of Cuban immigrants, is seen as a potential running mate who could help Trump as he tries to secure support from Hispanic Americans, a point the senator emphasized in his remarks as he switched several times in his remarks to Spanish.\n\nThe senator did not openly acknowledge any of the speculation about him joining Trump as a running mate. He instead skewered not only Biden, whom he called \"the figurehead of a left-wing government, shadow government,\" but Vice President Kamala Harris, whom he would need to debate head-on if he's chosen for Trump's ticket.\n\nRubio referred to Harris not by name at first but called her Biden's \"replacement\" and \"a real-life, verified left-winger.\" At another point in his remarks, he mocked the way Harris laughs.\n\nHe notably seemed to insert himself into Trump's signature \"Make America Great Again\" slogan by saying: \"Together, we're not just going to make it great again. We elect this man as president, we will make together America greater than it has ever been.\"\n\nKevin Cabrera, a Miami-Dade County commissioner who was Florida state director for Trump's 2020 reelection campaign, spoke at the rally, saying ahead of the event that it would be an \"overwhelming show of unity.\"\n\n\"The rally will display our unified front, showcasing a stark contrast to the Democrats, who are lost and fighting with each other over Biden's health and ability to continue,\" Cabrera said.\n\nOne attendee, 28-year-old Austin Stiglin, said he traveled from northern Florida to participate in his first Trump rally. He was wearing a star-patterned navy blue jacket and red pants and said he was \"tired of the left telling him to vote left just because I am gay.\"\n\n\"I have a lot more to say than just my sexual orientation,\" Stiglin said. \"I would like to vote for policies that support the United States.\"\n\nThe presumptive GOP nominee is expected in his remarks to touch on Biden's handling of immigration and the economy, highlighting the rise in home prices and goods. Trump will also talk about how Florida is affected by the increasing arrivals of immigrants as the final destination for many people illegally crossing the U.S.-Mexico border.\n\nThe leadership crisis among Democrats has perhaps given Trump a reason to wait for his VP announcement so as to not draw attention away from Biden's woes. Senior advisers and key allies say they still don't know whom Trump will choose as his running mate, and many believe the choice is still in flux.\n\nSpeaking on MSNBC Monday, Biden criticized Trump for not having held events since the debate and suggested he had been \"riding around in his golf cart.\"\n\nPrice reported from New York.\n\nMore from this section\n\nDirect Mail Benchmark Report 2024 reveals 61% of marketers have increased direct mail investments in the last year\n\nVice Capital Markets Launches Integration with Fannie Mae Mission Score API\n\nMocPOGO Pokemon GO Hacks Updated: Fixes Failed to Detect Location Error 12", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KULR-8 Local News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@kulr8.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "michelle_l_price@kulr8.com", "name": "Michelle L. Rubio spoke to the crowd earlier in the evening at a rally that also featured Trump's sons.\n\n\"Will I announce my VP in 90 minutes?\" a fundraising appeal from Trump asked, telling supporters that they were \"NOT going to want to miss this.\" Shortly before Trump took the stage, his campaign also released prepared remarks, including the phrase, \"Tonight, I am officially\" before abruptly cutting off, adding to the intrigue.\n\nBut Trump did not announce his pick, instead saying that he was \"officially\" challenging President Joe Biden to another debate -- this time without moderators -- a format he has pushed in recent days to needle the incumbent over a poor performance in their first showdown of the cycle.\n\nThroughout the event, held outdoors in sweltering temperatures, Trump teased Rubio. The former president discussed a proposal to exclude tipped wages from taxes, a plan which would require legislation passing the House and Senate, but suggested Rubio might not be be a senator much longer to vote on the idea.\n\n\"Marco, you're going to vote for it, I hope,\" Trump said. \"Well, you may or may not be there to vote for it, but you'll be involved.\"\n\nTrump has said Rubio is on his shortlist, also mentioning Senators JD Vance of Ohio and Tim Scott of South Carolina, as well as North Dakota Governor Doug Burgum as under consideration, in response to a question from Fox News host Sean Hannity during an interview aired Monday.\n\nTrump told Hannity he had yet to make a final decision on his pick but plans an announcement in the coming week, and suggested it could \"even be during the convention,\" which begins on July 15 in Milwaukee. Trump has suggested that announcing during the convention could increase viewership of televised event.\n\nTuesday's event marked Trump reemergence on the campaign trail after a stretch that saw the presumptive Republican nominee largely lay low. That alloweded media glare to focus on Biden as the president sought to quell a Democratic revolt after his debate performance left some in the party worrying that he would not be able to defeat Trump and should stand aside for another candidate.\n\nTrump is also holding a rally on Saturday in Pennsylvania before the Repuvlican convention.\n\nTrump's campaign trail resurgence comes as Cook Political Report updated their Electoral College analysis that shows a more favorable map for Trump in November. The report moved Nevada, Arizona and Georgia from \"toss up\" to \"lean\" Republican. {"uri": "8217889505", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "02:40:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T02:40:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T02:33:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/trump-toys-miami-crowd-rubio-021840922.html", "title": "Trump toys with Miami crowd  --  and Rubio  --  over vice presidential pick", "body": "DORAL, Florida -- Former President Donald Trump repeatedly name-dropped Sen. Marco Rubio throughout his rally here on Tuesday night, leaving the crowd in suspense over who he'd pick as running mate -- while also seemingly toying with the vice presidential hopeful.\n\nTrump pulled the rumors surrounding his running mate into the open early in his 75-minute speech. \"They'll probably be thinking that I'll be announcing Rubio as my vice president,\" he said about the journalists gathered to cover the rally, \"because that's a lot of press.\" Trump, who withheld naming his running mate, then moved on to a rant about President Joe Biden and the economy.\n\nAt another point in his speech, Trump asked the Florida Republican senator whether he'd support his proposal to remove taxes from tips before teasing the senator with, \"you may or not be there to vote for it -- but you'll be involved.\" He later talked about his closeness to Rubio, acknowledging that during the 2016 presidential race \"we had a vicious campaign for a while,\" before introducing all the members of the Florida GOP congressional delegation and state lawmakers who attended. It is, in a way, classic Trump: trying to drum up drama for the sake of attention, while demanding fealty from those who hope to advance their political careers on his coattails.\n\nRubio is reportedly on the vice presidential short list, one of the last big decisions that Trump has to announce before being officially designated as the party's nominee at the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee next week. Also thought to be at the top of the list are Sen. J.D. Vance of Ohio and North Dakota Gov. Doug Burgum.\n\nRubio ran against Trump in 2016 in a bitter primary, where the eventual winner dubbed Rubio as \"Little Marco\" and the two argued about the size of Trump's hands (and other body parts). But they later worked together during Trump's first term on policy toward Latin America, doubling the child tax credit and small business loans during the pandemic.\n\nTrump's rally, at his private golf club, was a reemergence of sorts. The former president has been uncharacteristically quiet since his debate with Biden, who is facing pressure from some members of his party and political pundits to drop out of the race after a disastrous performance. Trump last held a campaign rally in Virginia, the day after the June 27 presidential debate.\n\nDuring his speech, Trump mocked Biden over the debate and reports that have detailed how his aides shield him from public scrutiny about his age and mental acuity. He challenged Biden to debate him again this week and to play him at golf.\n\n\"Donald Trump hasn't been seen in public for 12 days, now he's inviting fictional serial killers to dinner, teasing lil' Marco Rubio, praising Project 2025 architect Tom Homan, and challenging the President of the United States to golf,\" Biden spokesperson James Singer said in a statement. \"Joe Biden doesn't have time for Donald Trump's weird antics -- he's busy leading America and defending the free world.\"\n\nBut Trump mainly focused the event on showing his dominance in Florida, the state where he switched his residency to during his time in the White House. Trump name-dropped Rubio, using his first name, throughout his speech.\n\nTrump sarcastically called Biden's selection of Vice President Kamala Harris the \"smartest decision he has ever made,\" sharing the nickname \"Laffin' Kamala\" and spelling it out for the crowd.\n\n\"It was the best insurance policy I have ever seen, Marco,\" Trump said, alluding to how certain Democratic operatives have expressed that they didn't think Harris could carry the ticket.\n\nRubio received the loudest applause from the audience of any members of the speaker lineup aside from Trump. He took the stage and oscillated between English and Spanish, providing audience members a preview of what it might look like for him to join Trump on the ticket and campaign alongside him. \"Can I say something in Spanglish?\" he asked at one point.\n\nRubio also provided insight into how he might go after Harris if he is picked as Trump's running mate, calling her a \"verified left winger\" and mocking her laugh. Should Rubio be picked as running mate, he and Harris could face off in a debate. However, both campaigns have ditched the Commission on Presidential Debates, and several media outlets have proposed vice presidential faceoffs.\n\n\"Of all the crazy, left-wing policies they wanted for our country -- she has supported every one of them,\" Rubio said, citing her support for reducing transit emissions and banning plastic straws (though she said the paper ones break too easily).\n\nRubio also drew support from fellow Floridian Sen. Rick Scott, who spoke before him onstage and praised him for doing \"an unbelievable job.\"\n\n\"And by the way -- he'd be a great vice presidential pick,\" Scott added.\n\nBut Rubio faces some opposition from within the former president's orbit. Donald Trump Jr., the president's son, said on his show \"Triggered\" that Rubio wouldn't be the best pick.\n\nTrump Jr. said he had a good relationship with Rubio, but agreed with a commentator who said the Floridian in the vice presidency would lead to another Trump impeachment. \"There is some truth about having someone that's a little bit more establishment in there,\" he said. \"Wouldn't the Senate RINOs, wouldn't they love that?\"\n\nThe younger Trump acknowledged that he was pulling for Vance, and said he \"has no inside information, obviously, but if I did I probably wouldn't tell you anyway.\"\n\nDuring a press conference earlier in the day, Florida Democratic Party Chair Nikki Fried promised the party would be on the \"front lines\" to oppose Rubio and would \"have stories to tell.\"\n\n\"We are the ones who've had to deal with Marco Rubio for the last few decades here in our state ... If he is going to decide to run for vice president of the United States, the No. 1 issue is he will once again have abandoned the people of this state,\" Fried said. She was alluding to how Rubio frequently missed hearings and votes in the Senate -- an issue he came under attack for when he ran for president in 2016 and during his 2022 reelection campaign, though that year he easily kept his seat.\n\nFried also criticized Rubio for comparing Trump's trial in Manhattan to those in communist Cuba.\n\n\"He is more concerned about kissing the ring than understanding where he came from,\" she said.\n\nHouse members from the Florida delegation who spoke at the rally didn't mention Rubio, instead focusing on praising Trump and ridiculing Biden's debate performance. They did, however, make overtures the Hispanic community, a crucial voting bloc in Florida -- especially in Miami-Dade, which is home to many voters of Cuban descent and where Trump's golf course is located.\n\n\"I would like to send a message to the Hispanic community across the country,\" said Rep. Maria Elvira Salazar (R-Fla.). \"You are welcomed in the Republican Party.\"", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8217909159", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "02:59:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T02:59:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T02:58:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.scmp.com/news/world/united-states-canada/article/3269848/trump-revels-biden-turmoil-he-returns-campaign-trail-and-teases-vp-pick", "title": "Trump revels in Biden campaign turmoil, teases VP pick at Florida rally", "body": "Donald Trump steps up attacks on Vice-President Kamala Harris at Miami Rally, teases Marco Rubio as his possible running mate\n\nFormer US president Donald Trump on Tuesday revelled in the mounting turmoil surrounding President Joe Biden \u2019s campaign in the wake of their debate and teased the expected announcement of his Republican running mate with one of the top contenders, Florida Senator Marco Rubio, in attendance.\n\nAfter days spent lying low, golfing and letting Democratic infighting play out in public, Trump used his return to the campaign trail in Florida to ratchet up his attacks on both Biden and Vice-President Kamala Harris, indulging speculation that she could replace the president as the Democratic nominee this year and alleging, without evidence, that his son Hunter Biden is \u201crunning our government\u201d and first lady Jill Biden \u201cis helping\u201d.\n\nBiden has repeatedly insisted he won\u2019t withdraw from the race.\n\nTrump rallied his supporters at one of his Miami-area golf courses as the presumptive Republican nominee nears a deadline to announce his running mate.\n\nBut he appears in no rush, as much of the political world\u2019s attention is still centred on questions about Biden\u2019s ability to govern for another four-year term. Some Democrats have started calling for Biden to step down as their presumptive nominee following his dismal debate performance last month.\n\nTrump, speaking from the 10th hole of his course, challenged Biden to another debate or even a \u201cgolf-off\u201d reviving an offbeat argument from their debate. But mostly, he rubbed in how their meetup left Biden\u2019s campaign facing a grim prognosis.\n\n\u201cOur victory was so absolute that Joe\u2019s own party now wants him to throw in the towel and surrender the presidency after a single 90-minute performance,\u201d Trump said Tuesday night. \u201cThey want \u2018Crooked Joe\u2019 out of the race. It\u2019s a shame the way they\u2019re treating him. But don\u2019t feel sorry for him. He\u2019s a very bad guy.\u201d\n\nJames Singer, a spokesperson for Biden\u2019s campaign, responded to Trump with a series of challenges, saying in a statement that: \u201cWe\u2019d challenge Donald Trump to create jobs, but he lost 3 million. We\u2019d challenge Donald Trump to stand up to Putin, but he bent the knee to him. We\u2019d challenge Donald Trump to follow the law, but he breaks it\u201d.\n\nSinger also said: \u201cJoe Biden doesn\u2019t have time for Donald Trump\u2019s weird antics \u2013 he\u2019s busy leading America and defending the free world\u201d.\n\nTrump laced into Harris with more specifics than usual. She has become a focus of the former president and his allies as speculation has mounted that she would replace Biden as the Democratic nominee.\n\nTrump called her \u201cLaughing Kamala\u201d and referred to the \u201cBiden-Harris administration\u201d, rather than just pinning actions on Biden as he had for months, and blamed Harris for the White House\u2019s immigration policies.\n\n\u201cDespite all the Democrat panic this week, the truth is, it doesn\u2019t matter who they nominate because we are going to beat any one of them in thundering landslides and this November\u2019s going to be amazing,\u201d he said.\n\nTrump, ever the showman, repeatedly played into the speculation that he might elevate Rubio to his ticket.\n\nRubio, a Miami native and one of the contenders for the vice-presidential post, was among the Florida politicians who spoke at the event.\n\nAt one point, Trump marvelled at the number of reporters in attendance and said: \u201cI think they probably think I\u2019m going to be announcing that Marco is going to be vice-president\u201d.\n\nLater, when he talked about his pledge to make tips tax-free, he remarked that Rubio \u201cmay or may not be there to vote for it\u201d.\n\nRubio, the son of Cuban immigrants, is seen as a potential running mate who could help Trump as he tries to secure support from Hispanic Americans, a point the senator emphasised in his remarks as he switched several times in his remarks to Spanish.\n\nThe senator did not openly acknowledge any of the speculation about him joining Trump as a running mate. He instead skewered not only Biden, whom he called \u201cthe figurehead of a left-wing government, shadow government,\u201d but Harris, whom he would need to debate head-on if he\u2019s chosen for Trump\u2019s ticket.\n\nRubio referred to Harris not by name at first but called her Biden\u2019s \u201creplacement\u201d and \u201ca real-life, verified left-winger\u201d. At another point in his remarks, he mocked the way Harris laughs.\n\nTrump has said Rubio is on his shortlist, also mentioning Senators JD Vance of Ohio and Tim Scott of South Carolina, as well as North Dakota Governor Doug Burgum as under consideration, in response to a question from Fox News host Sean Hannity during an interview aired Monday.\n\nAdditional reporting by Bloomberg", "source": officially challenging crooked Joe to an 18-hole golf match,\" Trump said.\n\nSinger took aim at Trump for not being on the campaign trail in the days following the debate.\n\n\"Donald Trump hasn't
