{"uri": "8217594738", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "20:31:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T20:31:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T20:31:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.ntd.com/trump-says-he-hasnt-made-final-decision-on-vp-as-deadline-approaches_1003954.html", "title": "Trump Says He Hasn't Made Final Decision on VP as Deadline Approaches", "body": "Republican presidential candidate, former President Donald Trump delivers remarks during the CNN Presidential Debate at the CNN Studios in Atlanta on June 27, 2024. (Justin Sullivan/Getty Images)\n\nFormer President Donald Trump on Monday indicated that he has not finalized who he will select as his vice presidential candidate, just days before the Republican nominating convention.\n\nDuring an interview with Fox News' Sean Hannity, the former president was asked about possible choices including Sens. J.D. Vance (R-Ohio), Marco Rubio (R-Fla.), and Tim Scott (R-S.C.), along with North Dakota Gov. Doug Burgum.\n\n\"The names that you mentioned, absolutely they're under consideration,\" the former president told the host. However, the former president said he hasn't \"made a final decision, but I have some ideas as to where we're going.\"\n\nFormer President Trump said he would \"love\" to announce his vice presidential pick during the Republican National Convention, which will be held in Milwaukee starting July 15. But he indicated that such a move might be \"a little complicated.\"\n\n\"Probably a little before the convention, but not much. It could even be during the convention that we'd do it,\" he said.\n\nWhile he did not make any indications on who he might choose on Monday, the former president provided more details on the type of person he wants as his No. 2. His running mate, he said, would have to be \"a person that can do a fantastic job as president,\" and \"somebody that helps you get elected.\"\n\nIn a separate interview, Trump campaign adviser Jason Miller said in a Monday interview with Fox News that the announcement \"could happen anytime this week\" or \"could happen literally right up until the first day of the convention.\"\n\nMr. Rubio, who ran against then-candidate Trump in 2016, will make an appearance at the former president's campaign rally at a Trump Doral golf club in Florida on Tuesday evening. On Saturday, the former president will hold a rally in a city located in western Pennsylvania, considered a battleground state, near the border with Ohio.\n\nOn July 7, the Florida senator mounted a defense of former President Trump during a CNN interview, pushing back on claims that the former president has close ties with the Heritage Foundation think tank's Project 2025. The former president late last week wrote on Truth Social that he has \"nothing to do with\" the project, which includes several former Trump administration officials.\n\nMr. Rubio also said he is fine with the former president's platform around abortion, which is more focused on states' rights.\n\n\"Our platform has to reflect our nominee, and our nominee's position happens to be one grounded in reality,\" Mr. Rubio told CNN, adding that \"voters at individual states who will get to decide how and to what level they want to restrict abortion, if at all.\"\n\nLater in the interview, he characterized the former president as the \"only one pro-life candidate in this race\" in response to questions about removing a federal abortion ban from the Republican Party's platform. \"You can't pass a federal law now even if we wanted to,\" he said.\n\nEarlier this week, Mr. Vance, a freshman senator with a finance background, told NBC News that he hasn't \"gotten the call\" from the Trump campaign about being the former president's vice presidential pick.\n\n\"We'll let the media know if I ever get that call,\" he said. \"But most importantly, we're just trying to work to elect Donald Trump. Whoever his vice president is, he's got a lot of good people he could choose from.\"\n\nMr. Burgum was asked last week by a Fox News anchor about whether he would want to be selected as vice president. \"I think the key thing for Kathryn and I has always been impact. We want to be in the spot where it can have the biggest impact,\" he replied, referring to his wife.\n\nThe Epoch Times contacted the Trump campaign for comment on Tuesday.", "source": {"uri": "ntd.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NTD"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNN", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "CNN"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Republican Party (United States)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_News", "type": "org", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Fox News"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marco_Rubio", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Marco Rubio"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Vice President of the United States"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doug_Burgum", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Doug Burgum"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._D._Vance", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "J. {"uri": "8218616890", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:41:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:41:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T11:41:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://mcdowellnews.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/trump-vp-announcement-rubio-vance-burgum/article_512d67f4-6bd9-586b-92c9-735c55412b9b.html", "title": "The plane is ready, the fundraisers are booked: Trump's VP search comes down to its final days", "body": "NEW YORK -- The future Republican vice presidential candidate's plane is currently parked in an undisclosed hangar, an empty spot on its fuselage where a decal featuring his or her name will soon be placed.\n\nFundraisers have been planned.\n\nAll that's left: an announcement from former President Donald Trump unveiling his pick.\n\nSenior advisers and longtime allies insist they still don't know whom the presumptive GOP nominee will choose to join him on the ticket -- with many believing the choice is still in flux.\n\n\"I haven't made (a) final decision. But I have some ideas as to where we're going,\" Trump said in an interview with Fox News Channel's Sean Hannity that aired Monday night.\n\nThe decision will come at an unprecedented time of upheaval in the presidential race. President Joe Biden and the Democratic Party continue to grapple with his dismal debate performance and the intensifying calls for the 81-year-old president to step aside in favor of a younger candidate.\n\nPeople are also reading... 3 dead in plane crash near McDowell, Rutherford county line Plane crashes in McDowell; emergency crews ask people to avoid Brackett Town Road Marion man meets McDowell paramedic who saved his life 24 years ago Toddler killed by truck at Steel Creek campground north of Morganton Golden Hour Charcuterie opens in Marion's Depot District 3 from South Carolina die in Nebo plane crash; national safety board investigating Body found Sunday was Marion man; cause of death pending toxicology report Nebo woman charged with break-in McDowell Little League crowns two champions; league to host a baseball state tournament Burkemont Mountain in Morganton ablaze with 30-acre wildfire When are the 4th of July fireworks, parades in McDowell County? McDowell calendar: Independence Day parades set for today Mission Hospital McDowell's new CEO planning to get to know the community Marion's Spillway Bridge & Co. set to reopen under new owners Man found dead near Lake James in McDowell County\n\nThe Democrats' crisis has given Trump little incentive to change the subject with a VP announcement that would be sure to draw a flurry of attention and focus.\n\nTrump has also been waiting to see how things shake out with Biden.\n\n\"A little bit, you know, we wanted to see what they're doing, to be honest. Because, you know, it might make a difference,\" he told Hannity.\n\nBut Trump will have plenty of opportunities this week to ratchet up the speculation about a process that his team has kept extraordinarily close to the vest.\n\n\"It could happen anytime this week,\" Trump senior adviser Jason Miller said in an appearance on Fox News.\n\nTrump has two rallies planned. The first is scheduled for Tuesday evening at his golf club in Doral, Florida, near Miami. The primetime scheduling and location would seem to provide an ideal opportunity to unveil his pick if it is Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, a Miami native who is one of his top contenders.\n\nRubio will be in attendance at the event, according to an adviser familiar with the senator's plans, who, like others, spoke on condition of anonymity about the selection process.\n\nOn Saturday Trump will travel to the critical battleground state of Pennsylvania for an afternoon rally at the Butler Farm Show. The venue, outside of Pittsburgh, is not far from the border of Ohio, which is home to Sen. JD Vance, another potential pick.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nAlso said to be on Trump's short list is North Dakota Gov. Doug Burgum, who has grown close to the former president since he dropped his own bid for the nomination before voting began.\n\nTrump doesn't need a rally to unveil his pick. He could simply announce the news on his Truth Social platform at any moment between now and the Republican National Convention, which kicks off in Milwaukee on July 15. Or he could wait until the convention opens to make a grand, on-stage curtain reveal reminiscent of his days as the host of the \"The Apprentice\" reality TV show.\n\nHe said Monday the announcement will come \"probably a little before the convention, but not much. It could even be during the convention that we'd do it. I'd love to do it during the convention. ... It would make it even more exciting.\"\n\nTrump has repeatedly said he intends to unveil his pick just before or during the convention. But he has been coy about his choice.\n\nLate last month, before the debate, Trump told NBC News at a campaign stop in Philadelphia that he'd already made a decision.\n\n\"In my mind, yeah,\" he said.\n\nBut less than a week later, he told a local Virginia television station that his decision was still in flux.\n\n\"Well I have people in mind. I have so many good people. We have such a deep bench,\" he said. \"But we'll be making a decision sometime early convention or before convention.\"\n\n\"As President Trump has said himself, the top criteria in selecting a Vice President is a strong leader who could make a great President,\" Trump adviser Brian Hughes said in a statement he has issued repeatedly. \"But anyone telling you they know who or when President Trump will choose his VP is lying unless that person is named Donald J. Trump.\"\n\nThat includes the front-runners for the job.\n\nOn CNN's \"State of the Union\" on Sunday, Rubio said he remained in the dark.\n\n\"Look, I've heard nothing, I know nothing, and you probably know more than I do about it,\" he said. \"Donald Trump has a decision to make. He'll make it when he needs to make it. He'll make a good decision. I know for certain that I will be out there over the next three or four months, working on behalf of his campaign in some capacity.\"\n\nHe also dismissed questions about whether he has discussed changing his residence from Florida if he's chosen as \"presumptuous.\" The Constitution bars the president and vice president from hailing from the same state.\n\n\"We'll confront those issues when they come,\" he said. \"But we're not there yet. But we will be soon, one way or the other.\"\n\nOn NBC's \"Meet the Press,\" Vance, too, said he has not received news one way or the other: \"I have not gotten the call.\"\n\n\"But most importantly,\" he went on, \"we're just trying to work to elect Donald Trump. Whoever his vice president is -- he's got a lot of good people he could choose from -- it's the policies that worked and the leadership style that worked for the American people. I think we have to bring that back to the White House, and I'm fighting to try to do that.\"\n\nCompanies donating the most money to Donald Trump Companies donating the most money to Donald Trump #22. {"uri": "2024-07-417395879", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:05:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:05:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T11:30:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://journalstar.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/trump-vp-announcement-rubio-vance-burgum/article_0336ef92-bca3-58cc-ba15-8310d04cc22a.html", "title": "The plane is ready, the fundraisers are booked: Trump's VP search comes down to its final days", "body": "NEW YORK -- The future Republican vice presidential candidate's plane is currently parked in an undisclosed hangar, an empty spot on its fuselage where a decal featuring his or her name will soon be placed.\n\nFundraisers have been planned.\n\nAll that's left: an announcement from former President Donald Trump unveiling his pick.\n\nSenior advisers and longtime allies insist they still don't know whom the presumptive GOP nominee will choose to join him on the ticket -- with many believing the choice is still in flux.\n\n\"I haven't made (a) final decision. But I have some ideas as to where we're going,\" Trump said in an interview with Fox News Channel's Sean Hannity that aired Monday night.\n\nThe decision will come at an unprecedented time of upheaval in the presidential race. President Joe Biden and the Democratic Party continue to grapple with his dismal debate performance and the intensifying calls for the 81-year-old president to step aside in favor of a younger candidate.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nCrete, Nebraska: 7 shot in 'welcoming community' by neighbor who 'hated everybody' Lincoln-based Valentino's closes A Street pizza shop Matt Rhule's 'right-hand man' leaves Nebraska football's coaching staff 'Grateful and excited': Megan Conway finds a landing anchor chair at 10/11 in Lincoln Big Chicken restaurant, founded by NBA star Shaquille O'Neal, is coming to Omaha Social media influencer Cam Wilder draws more than 1,000 to Lincoln park Lincoln man shot and killed Friday night in business parking lot Soft-serve survivors: How Zesto endured in Nebraska after its ice-cream empire melted Lincoln police identify victim, provide details from Friday night shooting Body of missing 17-year-old who jumped into Platte River to save girl found, authorities say Nebraska lawmakers 'bewildered' as Gov. Pillen's 'high risk' special session nears Report: NFL coach emerges as Nebraska's potential replacement for Evan Cooper Downtown Lincoln facelift: Corridor enchantment plan prioritizes pedestrians City Hall: NU will pay to use new youth baseball complex; city ballfields a source of concern Nebraska Gov. Jim Pillen vows tax plan will 'get the votes' despite shaky support\n\nThe Democrats' crisis has given Trump little incentive to change the subject with a VP announcement that would be sure to draw a flurry of attention and focus.\n\nTrump has also been waiting to see how things shake out with Biden.\n\n\"A little bit, you know, we wanted to see what they're doing, to be honest. Because, you know, it might make a difference,\" he told Hannity.\n\nBut Trump will have plenty of opportunities this week to ratchet up the speculation about a process that his team has kept extraordinarily close to the vest.\n\n\"It could happen anytime this week,\" Trump senior adviser Jason Miller said in an appearance on Fox News.\n\nTrump has two rallies planned. The first is scheduled for Tuesday evening at his golf club in Doral, Florida, near Miami. The primetime scheduling and location would seem to provide an ideal opportunity to unveil his pick if it is Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, a Miami native who is one of his top contenders.\n\nRubio will be in attendance at the event, according to an adviser familiar with the senator's plans, who, like others, spoke on condition of anonymity about the selection process.\n\nOn Saturday Trump will travel to the critical battleground state of Pennsylvania for an afternoon rally at the Butler Farm Show. The venue, outside of Pittsburgh, is not far from the border of Ohio, which is home to Sen. JD Vance, another potential pick.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nAlso said to be on Trump's short list is North Dakota Gov. Doug Burgum, who has grown close to the former president since he dropped his own bid for the nomination before voting began.\n\nTrump doesn't need a rally to unveil his pick. He could simply announce the news on his Truth Social platform at any moment between now and the Republican National Convention, which kicks off in Milwaukee on July 15. Or he could wait until the convention opens to make a grand, on-stage curtain reveal reminiscent of his days as the host of the \"The Apprentice\" reality TV show.\n\nHe said Monday the announcement will come \"probably a little before the convention, but not much. It could even be during the convention that we'd do it. I'd love to do it during the convention. ... It would make it even more exciting.\"\n\nTrump has repeatedly said he intends to unveil his pick just before or during the convention. But he has been coy about his choice.\n\nLate last month, before the debate, Trump told NBC News at a campaign stop in Philadelphia that he'd already made a decision.\n\n\"In my mind, yeah,\" he said.\n\nBut less than a week later, he told a local Virginia television station that his decision was still in flux.\n\n\"Well I have people in mind. I have so many good people. We have such a deep bench,\" he said. \"But we'll be making a decision sometime early convention or before convention.\"\n\n\"As President Trump has said himself, the top criteria in selecting a Vice President is a strong leader who could make a great President,\" Trump adviser Brian Hughes said in a statement he has issued repeatedly. \"But anyone telling you they know who or when President Trump will choose his VP is lying unless that person is named Donald J. Trump.\"\n\nThat includes the front-runners for the job.\n\nOn CNN's \"State of the Union\" on Sunday, Rubio said he remained in the dark.\n\n\"Look, I've heard nothing, I know nothing, and you probably know more than I do about it,\" he said. \"Donald Trump has a decision to make. He'll make it when he needs to make it. He'll make a good decision. I know for certain that I will be out there over the next three or four months, working on behalf of his campaign in some capacity.\"\n\nHe also dismissed questions about whether he has discussed changing his residence from Florida if he's chosen as \"presumptuous.\" The Constitution bars the president and vice president from hailing from the same state.\n\n\"We'll confront those issues when they come,\" he said. \"But we're not there yet. But we will be soon, one way or the other.\"\n\nOn NBC's \"Meet the Press,\" Vance, too, said he has not received news one way or the other: \"I have not gotten the call.\"\n\n\"But most importantly,\" he went on, \"we're just trying to work to elect Donald Trump. Whoever his vice president is -- he's got a lot of good people he could choose from -- it's the policies that worked and the leadership style that worked for the American people. I think we have to bring that back to the White House, and I'm fighting to try to do that.\"\n\nCompanies donating the most money to Donald Trump\n\nCompanies donating the most money to Donald Trump\n\n#22. Doug Burgum.\n\n\"The names that you mentioned, absolutely they're under consideration,\" the former president told the host. However, the former president said he hasn't \"made a final decision, but I have some ideas as to where we're going.\"\n\nFormer President Trump said he would \"love\" to announce his vice presidential pick during the Republican National Convention, which will be held in Milwaukee starting July 15. But he indicated that such a move might be \"a little complicated.\"\n\n\"Probably a little before the convention, but not much. It could even be during the convention that we'd do it,\" he said.\n\nWhile he did not make any indications on who he might choose on Monday, the former president provided more details on the type of person he wants as his No. 2. His running mate, he said, would have to be \"a person that can do a fantastic job as president,\" and \"somebody that helps you get elected.\"\n\nIn a separate interview, Trump campaign adviser Jason Miller said in a Monday interview with Fox News that the announcement \"could happen anytime this week\" or \"could happen literally right up until the first day of the convention.\"\n\nMr. Rubio, who ran against then-candidate Trump in 2016, will make an appearance at the former president's campaign rally at a Trump Doral golf club in Florida on Tuesday evening. On Saturday, the former president will hold a rally in a city located in western Pennsylvania, considered a battleground state, near the border with Ohio.\n\nOn July 7, the Florida senator mounted a defense of former President Trump during a CNN interview, pushing back on claims that the former president has close ties with the Heritage Foundation think tank's Project 2025. The former president late last week wrote on Truth Social that he has \"nothing to do with\" the project, which includes several former Trump administration officials.\n\nMr. Rubio also said he is fine with the former president's platform around abortion, which is more focused on states' rights.\n\n\"Our platform has to reflect our nominee, and our nominee's position happens to be one grounded in reality,\" Mr. Rubio told CNN, adding that \"voters at individual states who will get to decide how and to what level they want to restrict abortion, if at all.\"\n\nLater in the interview, he characterized the former president as the \"only one pro-life candidate in this race\" in response to questions about removing a federal abortion ban from the Republican Party's platform. \"You can't pass a federal law now even if we wanted to,\" he said.\n\n\"We'll let the media know if I ever get that call,\" he said. \"But most importantly, we're just trying to work to elect Donald Trump. Maybe bigger than the Ryder Cup or even the Masters.\n\nCLICK HERE FOR MORE SPORTS COVERAGE ON FOXNEWS.COM\n\n\"And I will even give Joe Biden 10 strokes a side. Ten strokes, that's a lot. That means 20 strokes, in case you don't play golf. And if he wins, I will give the charity of his choice, any charity of his choice, $1 million. He didn't hold back.\n\nSpeaking to thousands of supporters at Trump National Doral Miami, Trump piled on Biden, Vice President Kamala Harris and the entirety of the Democratic Party. He mocked Biden's performance at last month's presidential debate, and at one point, he challenged Biden to another debate -- and then an \"18-hole golf match.\"\n\n\"The radical left Democrat Party is divided, in chaos and having a full-scale breakdown because they can't decide which of their candidates is more unfit to be president. Sleepy Joe Biden or Laughing Kamala,\" Trump said to loud cheers.\n\nBiden, who beat Trump nearly four years ago, has spent the last 10 days trying to rehabilitate his image -- and his party's confidence in him -- following a floundering performance in the first presidential debate that intensified concerns about his age and fitness for office.\n\nSince then, Biden has faced growing calls from some in his own party -- including donors, lawmakers and voters -- to withdraw from the presidential race and make room for a new candidate to step in and challenge Trump, who vowed Tuesday to defeat any Democrat who runs against him.\n\n\"It doesn't matter who they nominate because we're going to beat any one of them,\" he said.\n\nWhile Biden has insisted that he will continue to seek a second term, some Republicans at Tuesday's rally saw the debate flub as a chance to bury Biden's campaign months before voters begin casting their ballots.\n\n\"We wanted to give the Democrats a little bit of time to self-destruct, and that's exactly what's happened over the past week and a half,\" said Kevin Cabrera, a Miami-Dade County Commissioner and a surrogate for the Trump campaign. \"They don't even know who their nominee is going to be right now, and we're here to rally around our candidate.\"\n\nIn the leadup to Trump's remarks, the rally more closely resembled a Fourth of July picnic rather than a political hypefest. Thousands of supporters sprawled out across the lawn of Trump's Doral golf course, while hundreds more crowded in a line for water bottles, hoping for some relief from near-triple-digit temperatures.\n\nSome attendees wafted themselves with American-flag-emblazoned paper fans. Taking the stage as the heat began to let up on Tuesday evening, U.S. Sen. The speech followed a day after Republican National Committee officials released the party's platform. Many of the ideas in the document are ones Trump has talked up in rally speeches since leaving office, including a \"drill baby drill\" energy policy, more tax cuts and the \"largest\" deportation effort in U.S. history.\n\nNo less prominent in his Tuesday rally address was an attack on President Joe Biden's competence -- an issue that has surged to the forefront of political conversations since a June 27 debate in which Biden appeared at times confused and incoherent.\n\nTrump again reiterated his \"offer\" to another debate with the current president. Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump ratcheted up his attacks on Vice-President Kamala Harris at a rally near Miami on July 9, trying to discredit her as the Democratic Party tussles over whether US President Joe Biden should remain in the race.\n\nSpeaking at his golf club in Doral, Florida, Trump stayed mum on his planned choice for his running mate, although he name-checked Florida Senator Marco Rubio, who was in attendance and is a leading contender for the role, multiple times.\n\nTaking the stage nearly an hour late on a hot night, Trump blasted the 81-year-old Biden about his shaky debate performance on June 27, which prompted worries about his mental fitness for office and calls from some Democrats for him to step aside.\n\nMr Biden said he had a bad night and that he will not drop out of the presidential race.\n\nIn a mocking tone, Trump called Mr Biden's choice of Ms Harris, the first Black and woman vice-president, his \"one brilliant decision,\" implying that she was so inept that Democrats were reluctant to replace Mr Biden with her on the top of the ticket.\n\n\"It was an insurance policy, maybe the best insurance policy I've ever seen,\" Trump said. \"If Joe had picked someone even halfway competent, they would have bounced him from office years ago.\"\n\nTrump also accused Ms Harris, a former US Senator and California attorney-general, of working with other Democrats on covering up Mr Biden's alleged mental acuity issues.\n\nMr Biden has said he has the stamina and mental sharpness to do the job.\n\nTrump also said Ms Harris's record would hurt her electoral chances, the latest sign that he and his Republican allies are starting an all-out assault on Ms Harris to prepare for Mr Biden possibly ending his re-election bid.\n\n\"I don't think Kamala Harris's California socialism is going to go down well with the people of Doral, the people of Miami or the people of Florida. Because in Florida we don't like socialism, we want our freedom,\" Trump said.\n\nThe Biden campaign accused Trump of lying about Ms Harris, and said he was trying to deflect from growing attention paid to Project 2025, a conservative group's controversial plans to remake the presidency should Trump win the Nov 5 election.\n\n\"Trump's bizarre and unhinged rants won't stop Vice-President Harris Trump offered to donate $1 million to a charity of Biden's choice if he were to lose the match.\n\nDuring a rally at the Blue Monster course in Doral, considered one of the world's greatest tournament golf courses, Trump said, \"I'm also officially challenging crooked Joe to an 18-hole golf match right here on Doral's Blue Monster, considered one of the greatest tournament golf courses anywhere in the world, one of the great courses of the world.It will be among the most-watched sporting events in history. Maybe bigger than the Ryder Cup or even the Masters.\"\n\nTrump even offered to give Biden a 10-stroke advantage per side, which equates to a total of 20 strokes. He added, \"And if he wins, I will give the charity of his choice, any charity of his choice, $1 million. And I'll bet you he doesn't take the offer.\"\n\nIn response, Biden's spokesperson, James Singer, criticised Trump's recent actions and statements, including his absence from the public eye, inviting fictional serial killers to dinner, praising Project 2025 architect Tom Homan, and challenging the President to a golf match. Singer emphasised that Biden is focused on leading the country and defending the free world, rather than engaging in Trump's antics.\n\n\"Donald Trump hasn't been seen in public for 12 days, now he's inviting fictional serial killers to dinner, teasing lil' Marco Rubio, praising Project 2025 architect Tom Homan, and challenging the President of the United States to golf,\" he said.\n\n\"We'd challenge Donald Trump to create jobs, but he lost 3 million. We'd challenge Donald Trump to stand up to Putin, but he bent the knee to him. We'd challenge Donald Trump to follow the law, but he breaks it. We'd challenge Donald Trump to not destroy our country, but that's all his Project 2025 aims to do,\" Singer added.\n\nSinger also asserted that \"Joe Biden doesn't have time for Donald Trump's weird antics - he's busy leading America and defending the free world. Donald Trump is a liar, a convict, and a fraud only out for himself - par for the course.\"\n\nThe golf handicap debate originated during the June 27 debate in Atlanta when Trump claimed to have won two club championships and questioned Biden's ability to drive a ball 50 yards. Biden initially said that he had a six handicap as vice president but later corrected it to an eight. Trump expressed disbelief, calling it \"the biggest lie.\"\n\nReigning US Open champion Bryson DeChambeau offered to host the golf match on his YouTube channel to help settle the handicap debate.\n\nAt TOI World Desk, our dedicated team of seasoned journalists and passionate writers tirelessly sifts through the vast tapestry of global events to bring you the latest news and diverse perspectives round the clock. he faces down calls to end his reelection bid after a disastrous debate performance.\n\nTrump's speech in Florida was his first public appearance since the clamor for Biden's withdrawal began gaining momentum, and the gloves were emphatically off as the Republican accused Democrats of lying to protect the president.\n\n\"It's the biggest cover up in political history,\" Trump thundered near the start of a 75-minute speech, which focused almost entirely on his 81-year-old election rival.\n\n\"As you know, they are all co-conspirators in the sinister plot to defraud the American public about the cognitive abilities of the man in the Oval Office.\"\n\nCommentators have noted how Trump, 78, has appeared relatively restrained in recent days, stepping back from the limelight to allow the full glare of the media to stay on the Democratic leadership crisis.\n\nBut he dispensed with any pretense at restraint as he characterized Biden as a \"corrupt, incompetent, cognitively impaired\" leader who was barely aware of his own policies or record in office.\n\nIn a typically bombastic speech peppered with multiple exaggerations and falsehoods, Trump accused Biden of going missing regularly from the Oval Office while his son Hunter, a convicted felon, runs the government aided by First Lady Jill Biden.\n\nFor much of the rally at his Doral National golf resort in Miami, Trump ran through his usual stump speech, characterizing America as teetering on the edge of catastrophe and describing a world facing a race against the clock to avert nuclear armageddon.\n\nBut there were multiple departures as Trump skewered Biden -- and kept twisting -- over numerous public statements from elected Democrats in recent days questioning his ability to carry the party to victory in November.\n\n- deadpanned.\n\n\"And I will even give Joe Biden 10 strokes a side... and if he wins, I will give the charity of his choice, any charity that he wants, $1 million. fraud only out for himself par for the course.\"\n\nFlorida Senator Marco Rubio is a frontrunner in the contest to be named Trump's running mate at next week's Republican nominating convention in Milwaukee, and he was in the front row to cheer on Trump and deliver brief remarks of his own.\n\nNearby, a digital billboard underscored the evolution that the Republican Party has undergone under Trump, playing 2016 footage of Rubio eviscerating the man he is hoping to work with for the next four years.\n\n\"You all have friends that are thinking about voting for Donald Trump,\" the now {"uri": "2024-07-416886489", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "03:18:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T03:18:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T03:15:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.com.au/trump-eyes-big-reveal-veepstakes-hits-final-stretch-1849380", "title": "Trump Eyes Big Reveal As Veepstakes Hits Final Stretch", "body": "With the pomp and pageantry of his official nomination just days away, Donald Trump's search for a running mate on the Republican presidential ticket is in the home stretch, with a trio of frontrunners jockeying to be first across the finish line.\n\nThe former US president is seeking a number two who can walk the delicate line between helping mobilize Trump's right-wing base and staying in lane as a sidekick who won't hog the limelight or, worse, prove more popular than the boss.\n\nTrump is expected to make his choice public during next week's Republican National Convention in Milwaukee, with an announcement anticipated as early as the opening day on Monday.\n\nThe billionaire appears to have zeroed in on two US senators, J.D. Vance of Ohio and Marco Rubio of Florida, as well as North Dakota Governor Doug Burgum, who initially ran against Trump for the nomination before falling in line.\n\nThe calculus might yet change, as Trump told Fox News on Monday that he was weighing a \"great bench\" of prospects and had not made a decision.\n\n\"It's going to be a great vice president, meaning a person that can do a fantastic job as president, because you always have to think of that first,\" he said.\n\n\"And then, second, somebody that helps you get elected. And there's nothing wrong with that.\"\n\nEver the consummate showman, Trump has been ramping up the intrigue, sending out a \"long list\" of contenders early on and offering conflicting accounts of how far along he was in the selection process.\n\nThere was speculation that he might use his first public appearance in 11 days to announce Rubio as he addressed supporters at his Doral golf club, on the outskirts of Miami.\n\nHe namechecked the senator, who was in the front row, several times but was silent on his thinking for the veepstakes.\n\nTrump could have dropped his big reveal at any point in the days before Milwaukee, except that the news would have interrupted arguably one of the worst weeks in the career of his 81-year-old rival Joe Biden.\n\nThe veteran Democrat is facing calls to drop out of the race after a widely-panned debate performance against Trump raised questions about the mental capacity of America's oldest-ever president.\n\n\"The big danger right now is because all the attention is focused on Biden, that if you announce anything, it will get lost,\" Republican strategist Rob Burgess, who worked on the Trump 2016 and 2020 campaigns, told AFP.\n\nOne of the biggest factors for Trump will be his running mate's fund-raising prowess, and the contenders have all been under pressure to showcase their connections with wealthy mega-donors.\n\nMeanwhile, the campaign has ensured that they are booked regularly for cable news interviews -- a kind of casting call that allows Trump to assess how they look in front of the cameras, a priority for the former reality TV star.\n\nTrump said before the June 27 debate that he already knew who his running mate would be, noting that his pick would likely be attending that night.\n\nThe three frontrunners were all bused to the CNN studio in Atlanta along with some less-favored hopefuls to watch from a volleyball court before being sent in to pitch for Trump on the press line.\n\nPolitical analyst Donald Nieman said he expected Vance to get the nod as an articulate messenger for Trumpism who is seen as a draw for working class white men in the crucial swing states of Pennsylvania, Michigan and Wisconsin.\n\nBut he added that a less \"thin-skinned\" Trump might have been persuaded to go with Nikki Haley, a one-time UN ambassador who was his last-standing rival in the nominating contest.\n\n\"She would bring Republican defectors and suburban women to Trump -- something he needs,\" Nieman, a history professor at Binghamton University in New York state, told AFP.\n\n\"But he won't because she hasn't signaled abject loyalty and a willingness to submerge her own identity.\"\n\nHaley, who says she is supporting Trump, has not been invited to the convention, according to Politico.\n\nIt remains to be seen in any case whether the successful candidate has what it takes to succeed where Mike Pence failed, and use the job as a springboard to the presidency.\n\n\"I'm not at all convinced that whoever Trump's vice president is, that he or she will have as significant a role as many of their predecessors,\" said constitutional expert Joel Goldstein, of Saint Louis University in Missouri.\n\n\"Although the vice president's role has grown, ultimately it depends upon the president's personality and his or her leadership style.\"", "source": {"uri": Biden's performance was so poor, some Democratic Party insiders called for him to drop his reelection bid. The president has remained defiant, however, and insists he is staying in the race.\n\n\"So, tonight, I'm officially offering Joe the chance to redeem himself in front of the entire world,\" Trump told rally-goers. \"Let's do another debate this week so that Sleepy Joe Biden can prove to everyone all over the world that he has what it takes to be president. But this time it will be man-to-man, no moderators, no-holds-barred. Just name the place anytime, anywhere.\"\n\nTrump then pivoted to an exchange he had with Biden regarding their respective golf games.\n\n\"And in the debate, Sleepy Joe also declared that he wanted to test his skills and stamina against mine on the golf course,\" he went on. \"Can you believe this? Did you ever see him swing?\"\n\nThe former president then mocked Biden by making a half-assed swinging motion.\n\n\"I'm also officially challenging Crooked Joe to an 18-hole golf match right here on Doral's Blue Monster [Trump National golf course], considered one of the greatest tournament golf courses anywhere in the world. One of the great courses in the world. It will be among the most-watched sporting events in history. Maybe bigger than the Ryder Cup or even the Masters.\"\n\nTrump added that he would spot Biden a 20-stroke lead.\n\n\"And if he wins, I will give the charity of his choice - any charity that he wants {"uri": "2024-07-416046378", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "10:05:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T10:05:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T10:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/4760633-donald-trump-jd-vance-marco-rubio-doug-burgum-vp/", "title": "Trump's VP search enters homestretch", "body": "Former President Trump's search for a running mate is entering the homestretch, with an announcement expected in the coming days.\n\nSources said the former president is still focused on Sens. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) and JD Vance (R-Ohio) and North Dakota Gov. Doug Burgum (R) as his top potential running mates, though Rubio and Vance have reportedly been at the center of discussions.\n\n\"If I were President Trump, I would make sure I pick somebody that could add value in 2024. Expand the map, take -- prosecute the case against the liberals,\" Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.), a Trump ally, said Sunday on \"Face the Nation.\"\n\nTrump is expected to make his choice public ahead of the Republican National Convention, which kicks off next Monday. One source close to the campaign said the former president could make the announcement at a Florida campaign rally on Tuesday, a Pennsylvania rally scheduled for Saturday, or, perhaps most likely, in a post on Truth Social.\n\n\"It could happen anytime this week. Could happen literally right up until the first day of the convention,\" senior Trump campaign adviser Jason Miller said Monday on Fox News.\n\nHowever, news of Trump's running mate announcement could potentially interrupt arguably one of the most negative news cycles of President Biden's administration.\n\n\"Outside of Election Day 2016, this has been the best two-week stretch of Donald Trump's political career,\" said Ford O'Connell, a Republican strategist. \"He's leading in national polls, he's leading in state polls, he's leading in cash on hand, and Democrats are talking about ejecting his opponent from the ticket. No way is he going to enter the fray.\"\n\nBoth Vance and Rubio said Sunday they had not heard one way or the other about whether they were the pick to join Trump on the ticket.\n\nAll three men -- Vance, Rubio and Burgum -- have their backers and detractors lobbying for or against them.\n\nThe Wall Street Journal pegged Burgum as the \"best man\" for the job, citing his ability to govern and his business background, while critics have questioned whether the red-state governor would do much to expand Trump's appeal.\n\nRep. Jim Banks (R-Ind.) and some other lawmakers have advocated for Vance, praising him as the face of the America First movement in Congress and a capable messenger for the ticket. But skeptics have questioned if Vance, who is a first-term senator, has the experience needed to serve as vice president alongside Trump, who is 78 and limited to one more term.\n\nRubio's allies have argued the senator could help expand Trump's appeal to minority voters, which could chip away at President Biden's coalition and potentially flip swing states in Trump's favor. Rubio and Trump were bitter rivals in the 2016 presidential race, though, and the senator would need to move outside of Florida in order to join the ticket.\n\n\"There's been no indication when it will be or who it will be. President Trump and his team have done an epic job building suspense,\" said one Republican strategist familiar with the process.\n\nThe Trump campaign has for weeks been tight-lipped about any developments in the search for a running mate, saying only the former president knows whom he will ultimately pick.\n\n\"As President Trump has said himself, the top criteria in selecting a vice president is a strong leader who could make a great President,\" senior campaign adviser Brian Hughes said in a statement. \"But anyone telling you they know who or when President Trump will choose his VP is lying unless that person is named Donald J. Trump.\"\n\nThe Trump campaign last month sent vetting materials to several candidates. In addition to the finalists, the campaign was in touch with Rep. Elise Stefanik (R-N.Y.), Rep. Byron Donalds (R-Fla.), Sen. Tom Cotton (R-Ark.), Sen. Tim Scott (R-S.C.) and former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development Ben Carson.\n\nWhile Trump zeroes in on his choice, some Republicans have pushed for the former president to consider a running mate with broad appeal to more moderate voters who could bolster his standing in swing states.\n\nSome Republicans have suggested that Trump should consider choosing Virginia Gov. Glenn Youngkin (R) as his running mate, citing Youngkin's appeal outside of Trump circles. The chatter around the governor comes as Republicans feel increasingly optimistic about Virginia, a state that hasn't gone for the party since 2004.\n\n\"Somebody's not being talked about, that should be in my view, is Youngkin from Virginia. If we win Virginia, we win. It is over,\" Graham said in the same interview on \"Face the Nation.\"\n\nTrump said last month at his postdebate rally in Virginia that he is \"considering\" Youngkin as an option. Youngkin, in turn, has responded to the speculation, saying he is \"humbled\" but focused on his current job.\n\nWhen asked about the running mate speculation surrounding Youngkin, Trump donor Dan Eberhart said \"maybe, but he isn't MAGA.\"", "source": {"uri": "thehill.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Hill"}, "authors": [{"uri": "brett_samuels@thehill.com", "name": "Brett Samuels", {"uri": "8218622609", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:45:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:45:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T11:44:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.stltoday.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/trump-vp-announcement-rubio-vance-burgum/article_cb07b5b2-a912-584d-9349-f7f7a60a8048.html", "title": "The plane is ready, the fundraisers are booked: Trump's VP search comes down to its final days", "body": "NEW YORK -- The future Republican vice presidential candidate's plane is currently parked in an undisclosed hangar, an empty spot on its fuselage where a decal featuring his or her name will soon be placed.\n\nFundraisers have been planned.\n\nAll that's left: an announcement from former President Donald Trump unveiling his pick.\n\nSenior advisers and longtime allies insist they still don't know whom the presumptive GOP nominee will choose to join him on the ticket -- with many believing the choice is still in flux.\n\n\"I haven't made (a) final decision. But I have some ideas as to where we're going,\" Trump said in an interview with Fox News Channel's Sean Hannity that aired Monday night.\n\nPi Pizzeria closing last remaining location, in St. Louis' Central West End McClellan: Downtown St. Louis is a casualty of the do-gooder war Tropical Storm Beryl could hit St. Louis area with 4 inches of rain or more Hulk Hogan starts selling his new Real American Beer in Missouri, competing with Bud Light BenFred: Why Jordan Walker's name will provide hot-stove fodder as Cardinals near trade deadline Wentzville schools investigated board members for alleged retaliation, ethics violations Parades, fireworks and parties: Your guide to July 4th in St. Louis Several St. Louis-area cities move fireworks shows to Friday. Others cancel events. Messenger: She sold her house to help support her baby. Missouri's AG wants the money. Two dead in North County, 7 injured in downtown St. Louis during Fourth of July shootings Lars Nootbaar wondered about his spate of injuries, too. So he sought answers: Cardinals Extra July 4 chaos reignites safety concerns in downtown St. Louis. Chief blames 'small' group. Messenger: Judge fines St. Louis attorney for hiding documents on police shootings Extra! Extra! Read all about Cardinals' comeback from 5-run deficit to outlast Nats in 11th BenFred: Eli Drinkwitz's relentless recruiting has Mizzou beating brand names in away games\n\nThe decision will come at an unprecedented time of upheaval in the presidential race. President Joe Biden and the Democratic Party continue to grapple with his dismal debate performance and the intensifying calls for the 81-year-old president to step aside in favor of a younger candidate.\n\nThe Democrats' crisis has given Trump little incentive to change the subject with a VP announcement that would be sure to draw a flurry of attention and focus.\n\nTrump has also been waiting to see how things shake out with Biden.\n\n\"A little bit, you know, we wanted to see what they're doing, to be honest. Because, you know, it might make a difference,\" he told Hannity.\n\nBut Trump will have plenty of opportunities this week to ratchet up the speculation about a process that his team has kept extraordinarily close to the vest.\n\n\"It could happen anytime this week,\" Trump senior adviser Jason Miller said in an appearance on Fox News.\n\nTrump has two rallies planned. The first is scheduled for Tuesday evening at his golf club in Doral, Florida, near Miami. The primetime scheduling and location would seem to provide an ideal opportunity to unveil his pick if it is Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, a Miami native who is one of his top contenders.\n\nRubio will be in attendance at the event, according to an adviser familiar with the senator's plans, who, like others, spoke on condition of anonymity about the selection process.\n\nOn Saturday Trump will travel to the critical battleground state of Pennsylvania for an afternoon rally at the Butler Farm Show. The venue, outside of Pittsburgh, is not far from the border of Ohio, which is home to Sen. JD Vance, another potential pick.\n\nAlso said to be on Trump's short list is North Dakota Gov. Doug Burgum, who has grown close to the former president since he dropped his own bid for the nomination before voting began.\n\nTrump doesn't need a rally to unveil his pick. He could simply announce the news on his Truth Social platform at any moment between now and the Republican National Convention, which kicks off in Milwaukee on July 15. Or he could wait until the convention opens to make a grand, on-stage curtain reveal reminiscent of his days as the host of the \"The Apprentice\" reality TV show.\n\nHe said Monday the announcement will come \"probably a little before the convention, but not much. It could even be during the convention that we'd do it. I'd love to do it during the convention. ... It would make it even more exciting.\"\n\nTrump has repeatedly said he intends to unveil his pick just before or during the convention. But he has been coy about his choice.\n\nLate last month, before the debate, Trump told NBC News at a campaign stop in Philadelphia that he'd already made a decision.\n\n\"In my mind, yeah,\" he said.\n\nBut less than a week later, he told a local Virginia television station that his decision was still in flux.\n\n\"Well I have people in mind. I have so many good people. We have such a deep bench,\" he said. \"But we'll be making a decision sometime early convention or before convention.\"\n\n\"As President Trump has said himself, the top criteria in selecting a Vice President is a strong leader who could make a great President,\" Trump adviser Brian Hughes said in a statement he has issued repeatedly. \"But anyone telling you they know who or when President Trump will choose his VP is lying unless that person is named Donald J. Trump.\"\n\nThat includes the front-runners for the job.\n\nOn CNN's \"State of the Union\" on Sunday, Rubio said he remained in the dark.\n\n\"Look, I've heard nothing, I know nothing, and you probably know more than I do about it,\" he said. \"Donald Trump has a decision to make. He'll make it when he needs to make it. He'll make a good decision. I know for certain that I will be out there over the next three or four months, working on behalf of his campaign in some capacity.\"\n\nHe also dismissed questions about whether he has discussed changing his residence from Florida if he's chosen as \"presumptuous.\" The Constitution bars the president and vice president from hailing from the same state.\n\n\"We'll confront those issues when they come,\" he said. \"But we're not there yet. But we will be soon, one way or the other.\"\n\nOn NBC's \"Meet the Press,\" Vance, too, said he has not received news one way or the other: \"I have not gotten the call.\"\n\n\"But most importantly,\" he went on, \"we're just trying to work to elect Donald Trump. Whoever his vice president is -- he's got a lot of good people he could choose from -- it's the policies that worked and the leadership style that worked for the American people. I think we have to bring that back to the White House, and I'm fighting to try to do that.\"\n\n0 Comments", "source": {"uri": "stltoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "St. Louis Post-Dispatch"}, {"uri": "2024-07-416889769", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "03:26:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T03:26:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T03:11:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/trump-eyes-big-reveal-veepstakes-031154150.html", "title": "Trump eyes big reveal as veepstakes hits final stretch", "body": "With the pomp and pageantry of his official nomination just days away, Donald Trump's search for a running mate on the Republican presidential ticket is in the home stretch, with a trio of frontrunners jockeying to be first across the finish line.\n\nThe former US president is seeking a number two who can walk the delicate line between helping mobilize Trump's right-wing base and staying in lane as a sidekick who won't hog the limelight or, worse, prove more popular than the boss.\n\nTrump is expected to make his choice public during next week's Republican National Convention in Milwaukee, with an announcement anticipated as early as the opening day on Monday.\n\nThe billionaire appears to have zeroed in on two US senators, J.D. Vance of Ohio and Marco Rubio of Florida, as well as North Dakota Governor Doug Burgum, who initially ran against Trump for the nomination before falling in line.\n\nThe calculus might yet change, as Trump told Fox News on Monday that he was weighing a \"great bench\" of prospects and had not made a decision.\n\n\"It's going to be a great vice president, meaning a person that can do a fantastic job as president, because you always have to think of that first,\" he said.\n\n\"And then, second, somebody that helps you get elected. And there's nothing wrong with that.\"\n\nEver the consummate showman, Trump has been ramping up the intrigue, sending out a \"long list\" of contenders early on and offering conflicting accounts of how far along he was in the selection process.\n\nThere was speculation that he might use his first public appearance in 11 days to announce Rubio as he addressed supporters at his Doral golf club, on the outskirts of Miami.\n\nHe namechecked the senator, who was in the front row, several times but was silent on his thinking for the veepstakes.\n\n- Casting call -\n\nTrump could have dropped his big reveal at any point in the days before Milwaukee, except that the news would have interrupted arguably one of the worst weeks in the career of his 81-year-old rival Joe Biden.\n\nThe veteran Democrat is facing calls to drop out of the race after a widely-panned debate performance against Trump raised questions about the mental capacity of America's oldest-ever president.\n\n\"The big danger right now is because all the attention is focused on Biden, that if you announce anything, it will get lost,\" Republican strategist Rob Burgess, who worked on the Trump 2016 and 2020 campaigns, told AFP.\n\nOne of the biggest factors for Trump will be his running mate's fund-raising prowess, and the contenders have all been under pressure to showcase their connections with wealthy mega-donors.\n\nMeanwhile, the campaign has ensured that they are booked regularly for cable news interviews -- a kind of casting call that allows Trump to assess how they look in front of the cameras, a priority for the former reality TV star.\n\nTrump said before the June 27 debate that he already knew who his running mate would be, noting that his pick would likely be attending that night.\n\nThe three frontrunners were all bused to the CNN studio in Atlanta along with some less-favored hopefuls to watch from a volleyball court before being sent in to pitch for Trump on the press line.\n\n- Big role? -\n\nPolitical analyst Donald Nieman said he expected Vance to get the nod as an articulate messenger for Trumpism who is seen as a draw for working class white men in the crucial swing states of Pennsylvania, Michigan and Wisconsin.\n\nBut he added that a less \"thin-skinned\" Trump might have been persuaded to go with Nikki Haley, a one-time UN ambassador who was his last-standing rival in the nominating contest.\n\n\"She would bring Republican defectors and suburban women to Trump -- something he needs,\" Nieman, a history professor at Binghamton University in New York state, told AFP.\n\n\"But he won't because she hasn't signaled abject loyalty and a willingness to submerge her own identity.\"\n\nHaley, who says she is supporting Trump, has not been invited to the convention, according to Politico.\n\nIt remains to be seen in any case whether the successful candidate has what it takes to succeed where Mike Pence failed, and use the job as a springboard to the presidency.\n\n\"I'm not at all convinced that whoever Trump's vice president is, that he or she will have as significant a role as many of their predecessors,\" said constitutional expert Joel Goldstein, of Saint Louis University in Missouri.\n\n\"Although the vice president's role has grown, ultimately it depends upon the president's personality and his or her leadership style.\"", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [{"uri": "frankie_taggart@yahoo.com", "name": "Frankie Taggart", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], Trump further said that should Joe Biden defeat him in the match, he will donate 1 million USD to a charity of Biden's choice. The former president was speaking at a rally in Florida.\n\n\"I'm also officially challenging crooked Joe to an 18-hole golf match right here on Doral's Blue Monster, considered one of the greatest tournament golf courses anywhere in the world, one of the great courses of the world,\" Trump said during his speech.\n\n\"It will be among the most-watched sporting events in history. Maybe bigger than the Ryder Cup or even the Masters,\" he added.\n\n\"And I will even give Joe Biden 10 strokes a side. Ten strokes, that's a lot. That means 20 strokes, in case you don't play golf. And if he wins, I will give the charity of his choice, any charity of his choice, $1 million. And I'll bet you he doesn't take the offer.\"\n\nBiden turns down the challenge. His spokesperson James Singer issued a statement which was quoted by US media.\n\n\"Donald Trump hasn't been seen in public for 12 days, now he's inviting fictional serial killers to dinner, teasing lil' Marco Rubio, praising Project 2025 architect Tom Homan, and challenging the President of the United States to golf,\" his statement said, as reported by Fox News.\n\n\"Joe Biden doesn't have time for Donald Trump's weird antics - he's busy leading America and defending the free world. Donald Trump is a liar, a convict, and a fraud only out for himself - par for the course.\"\n\nA taunt?\n\nTrump's challenge for Biden is being seen as his way of taking a shot at the president's health. Biden is already facing flak for what is increasingly appearing to be bad physical and even cognitive health. He is famous for his gaffes, forgetfulness and even physical tumbles in full public view. Many consider him unfit for a second term as US president.\n\nHis lacklustre performance in recently held US presidential debate has sent a scare through the Democratic Party. {"uri": "8218655098", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:06:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:06:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:05:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://magicvalley.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/trump-vp-announcement-rubio-vance-burgum/article_9ff6c2a2-a5c4-5fbe-ba1a-35b1a6305b59.html", "title": "The plane is ready, the fundraisers are booked: Trump's VP search comes down to its final days", "body": "NEW YORK -- The future Republican vice presidential candidate's plane is currently parked in an undisclosed hangar, an empty spot on its fuselage where a decal featuring his or her name will soon be placed.\n\nFundraisers have been planned.\n\nAll that's left: an announcement from former President Donald Trump unveiling his pick.\n\nSenior advisers and longtime allies insist they still don't know whom the presumptive GOP nominee will choose to join him on the ticket -- with many believing the choice is still in flux.\n\n\"I haven't made (a) final decision. But I have some ideas as to where we're going,\" Trump said in an interview with Fox News Channel's Sean Hannity that aired Monday night.\n\nThe decision will come at an unprecedented time of upheaval in the presidential race. President Joe Biden and the Democratic Party continue to grapple with his dismal debate performance and the intensifying calls for the 81-year-old president to step aside in favor of a younger candidate.\n\nPeople are also reading... Twin Falls County Most Wanted Police release photos of possible suspects after Twin Falls gunshot death Police: Man charged with DUI, eluding and battery after Twin Falls pursuit Twin Falls man charged with murder ISP: Buhl woman charged with DUI, leaving crash that left individual seriously injured Death Notices Man's body recovered from Snake River near Centennial Park Twin Falls infant hospitalized after possible drug exposure Gunshot victim taken to hospital; Twin Falls police pursue leads COMMENTARY: Don't do it BLASTING AWAY: Twin Falls man controls the fireworks shows Retail Therapy Boutique wants to be your cheerleader Death Notices Death Notices JONES: Two remarkable Idahoans were in the news in June\n\nThe Democrats' crisis has given Trump little incentive to change the subject with a VP announcement that would be sure to draw a flurry of attention and focus.\n\nTrump has also been waiting to see how things shake out with Biden.\n\n\"A little bit, you know, we wanted to see what they're doing, to be honest. Because, you know, it might make a difference,\" he told Hannity.\n\nBut Trump will have plenty of opportunities this week to ratchet up the speculation about a process that his team has kept extraordinarily close to the vest.\n\n\"It could happen anytime this week,\" Trump senior adviser Jason Miller said in an appearance on Fox News.\n\nTrump has two rallies planned. The first is scheduled for Tuesday evening at his golf club in Doral, Florida, near Miami. The primetime scheduling and location would seem to provide an ideal opportunity to unveil his pick if it is Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, a Miami native who is one of his top contenders.\n\nRubio will be in attendance at the event, according to an adviser familiar with the senator's plans, who, like others, spoke on condition of anonymity about the selection process.\n\nOn Saturday Trump will travel to the critical battleground state of Pennsylvania for an afternoon rally at the Butler Farm Show. The venue, outside of Pittsburgh, is not far from the border of Ohio, which is home to Sen. JD Vance, another potential pick.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nAlso said to be on Trump's short list is North Dakota Gov. Doug Burgum, who has grown close to the former president since he dropped his own bid for the nomination before voting began.\n\nTrump doesn't need a rally to unveil his pick. He could simply announce the news on his Truth Social platform at any moment between now and the Republican National Convention, which kicks off in Milwaukee on July 15. Or he could wait until the convention opens to make a grand, on-stage curtain reveal reminiscent of his days as the host of the \"The Apprentice\" reality TV show.\n\nHe said Monday the announcement will come \"probably a little before the convention, but not much. It could even be during the convention that we'd do it. I'd love to do it during the convention. ... It would make it even more exciting.\"\n\nTrump has repeatedly said he intends to unveil his pick just before or during the convention. But he has been coy about his choice.\n\nLate last month, before the debate, Trump told NBC News at a campaign stop in Philadelphia that he'd already made a decision.\n\n\"In my mind, yeah,\" he said.\n\nBut less than a week later, he told a local Virginia television station that his decision was still in flux.\n\n\"Well I have people in mind. I have so many good people. We have such a deep bench,\" he said. \"But we'll be making a decision sometime early convention or before convention.\"\n\n\"As President Trump has said himself, the top criteria in selecting a Vice President is a strong leader who could make a great President,\" Trump adviser Brian Hughes said in a statement he has issued repeatedly. \"But anyone telling you they know who or when President Trump will choose his VP is lying unless that person is named Donald J. Trump.\"\n\nThat includes the front-runners for the job.\n\nOn CNN's \"State of the Union\" on Sunday, Rubio said he remained in the dark.\n\n\"Look, I've heard nothing, I know nothing, and you probably know more than I do about it,\" he said. \"Donald Trump has a decision to make. He'll make it when he needs to make it. He'll make a good decision. I know for certain that I will be out there over the next three or four months, working on behalf of his campaign in some capacity.\"\n\nHe also dismissed questions about whether he has discussed changing his residence from Florida if he's chosen as \"presumptuous.\" The Constitution bars the president and vice president from hailing from the same state.\n\n\"We'll confront those issues when they come,\" he said. \"But we're not there yet. But we will be soon, one way or the other.\"\n\nOn NBC's \"Meet the Press,\" Vance, too, said he has not received news one way or the other: \"I have not gotten the call.\"\n\n\"But most importantly,\" he went on, \"we're just trying to work to elect Donald Trump. Whoever his vice president is -- he's got a lot of good people he could choose from -- it's the policies that worked and the leadership style that worked for the American people. I think we have to bring that back to the White House, and I'm fighting to try to do that.\"\n\nCompanies donating the most money to Donald Trump Companies donating the most money to Donald Trump #22. "Trump torches Biden as gloves finally come off after debate", "body": "Donald Trump unleashed a torrent of invective against President Joe Biden on Tuesday, mercilessly assailing the embattled Democrat as he faces down calls to end his reelection bid after a disastrous debate performance.\n\nTrump's speech in Florida was his first public appearance since the clamor for Biden's withdrawal began gaining momentum, and the gloves were emphatically off as the Republican accused Democrats of lying to protect the president.\n\n\"It's the biggest cover up in political history,\" Trump thundered near the start of a 75-minute speech, which focused almost entirely on his 81-year-old election rival.\n\n\"As you know, they are all co-conspirators in the sinister plot to defraud the American public about the cognitive abilities of the man in the Oval Office.\"\n\nCommentators have noted how Trump, 78, has appeared relatively restrained in recent days, stepping back from the limelight to allow the full glare of the media to stay on the Democratic leadership crisis.\n\nBut he dispensed with any pretense at restraint as he characterized Biden as a \"corrupt, incompetent, cognitively impaired\" leader who was barely aware of his own policies or record in office.\n\nIn a typically bombastic speech peppered with multiple exaggerations and falsehoods, Trump accused Biden of going missing regularly from the Oval Office while his son Hunter, a convicted felon, runs the government aided by First Lady Jill Biden.\n\nFor much of the rally at his Doral National golf resort in Miami, Trump ran through his usual stump speech, characterizing America as teetering on the edge of catastrophe and describing a world facing a race against the clock to avert nuclear armageddon.\n\nBut there were multiple departures as Trump skewered Biden -- and kept twisting -- over numerous public statements from elected Democrats in recent days questioning his ability to carry the party to victory in November.\n\n- Golf challenge -\n\nThe former president dared his successor to another debate without moderators and, in a lighter moment that raised a smile from audience members baking in 103-degree Fahrenheit (39-degree Celsius) heat, challenged him to a round of golf.\n\n\"It will be among the most watched sporting events in history, maybe bigger than the Ryder Cup or even the Masters,\" he deadpanned.\n\n\"And I will even give Joe Biden 10 strokes a side... and if he wins, I will give the charity of his choice, any charity that he wants, $1 million. And I bet you he doesn't take the offer.\"\n\nThe pair had previously sparred over who had a better long game during the debate, and the Biden campaign's response to the latest challenge came in the form of a golf pun.\n\n\"Joe Biden doesn't have time for Donald Trump's weird antics -- he's busy leading America and defending the free world,\" it said.\n\n\"Donald Trump is a liar, a convict, and a fraud only out for himself par for the course.\"\n\nFlorida Senator Marco Rubio is a frontrunner in the contest to be named Trump's running mate at next week's Republican nominating convention in Milwaukee, and he was in the front row to cheer on Trump and deliver brief remarks of his own.\n\nNearby, a digital billboard underscored the evolution that the Republican Party has undergone under Trump, playing 2016 footage of Rubio eviscerating the man he is hoping to work with for the next four years.\n\n\"You all have friends that are thinking about voting for Donald Trump,\" the now staunchly loyal Rubio was seen telling a crowd in Texas. \"Friends do not let friends vote for con artists.\"\n\nbur-ft/des\n\nMore from this section\n\nInformative Research Adds Brandon Hall as New {"uri": "8217991174", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "04:28:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T04:28:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T04:26:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.bssnews.net/news/199447", "title": "Trump eyes big reveal as veepstakes hits final stretch | News", "body": "WASHINGTON, July 10, 2024 (BSS/AFP) - With the pomp and pageantry of his official nomination just days away, Donald Trump's search for a running mate on the Republican presidential ticket is in the home stretch, with a trio of frontrunners jockeying to be first across the finish line.\n\nThe former US president is seeking a number two who can walk the delicate line between helping mobilize Trump's right-wing base and staying in lane as a sidekick who won't hog the limelight or, worse, prove more popular than the boss.\n\nTrump is expected to make his choice public during next week's Republican National Convention in Milwaukee, with an announcement anticipated as early as the opening day on Monday.\n\nThe billionaire appears to have zeroed in on two US senators, J.D. Vance of Ohio and Marco Rubio of Florida, as well as North Dakota Governor Doug Burgum, who initially ran against Trump for the nomination before falling in line.\n\nThe calculus might yet change, as Trump told Fox News on Monday that he was weighing a \"great bench\" of prospects and had not made a decision.\n\n\"It's going to be a great vice president, meaning a person that can do a fantastic job as president, because you always have to think of that first,\" he said.\n\n\"And then, second, somebody that helps you get elected. And there's nothing wrong with that.\"\n\nEver the consummate showman, Trump has been ramping up the intrigue, sending out a \"long list\" of contenders early on and offering conflicting accounts of how far along he was in the selection process.\n\nThere was speculation that he might use his first public appearance in 11 days to announce Rubio as he addressed supporters at his Doral golf club, on the outskirts of Miami.\n\nHe namechecked the senator, who was in the front row, several times but was silent on his thinking for the veepstakes.\n\n- Casting call -\n\nTrump could have dropped his big reveal at any point in the days before Milwaukee, except that the news would have interrupted arguably one of the worst weeks in the career of his 81-year-old rival Joe Biden.\n\nThe veteran Democrat is facing calls to drop out of the race after a widely-panned debate performance against Trump raised questions about the mental capacity of America's oldest-ever president.\n\n\"The big danger right now is because all the attention is focused on Biden, that if you announce anything, it will get lost,\" Republican strategist Rob Burgess, who worked on the Trump 2016 and 2020 campaigns, told AFP.\n\nOne of the biggest factors for Trump will be his running mate's fund-raising prowess, and the contenders have all been under pressure to showcase their connections with wealthy mega-donors.\n\nMeanwhile, the campaign has ensured that they are booked regularly for cable news interviews -- a kind of casting call that allows Trump to assess how they look in front of the cameras, a priority for the former reality TV star.\n\nTrump said before the June 27 debate that he already knew who his running mate would be, noting that his pick would likely be attending that night.\n\nThe three frontrunners were all bused to the CNN studio in Atlanta along with some less-favored hopefuls to watch from a volleyball court before being sent in to pitch for Trump on the press line.\n\n- Big role? -\n\nPolitical analyst Donald Nieman said he expected Vance to get the nod as an articulate messenger for Trumpism who is seen as a draw for working class white men in the crucial swing states of Pennsylvania, Michigan and Wisconsin.\n\nBut he added that a less \"thin-skinned\" Trump might have been persuaded to go with Nikki Haley, a one-time UN ambassador who was his last-standing rival in the nominating contest.\n\n\"She would bring Republican defectors and suburban women to Trump -- something he needs,\" Nieman, a history professor at Binghamton University in New York state, told AFP.\n\n\"But he won't because she hasn't signaled abject loyalty and a willingness to submerge her own identity.\"\n\nHaley, who says she is supporting Trump, has not been Vance of Ohio and Marco Rubio of Florida, as well as North Dakota Governor Doug Burgum, who initially ran against Trump for the nomination before falling in line.\n\nThe calculus might yet change, as Trump told Fox News on Monday that he was weighing a \"great bench\" of prospects and had not made a decision.\n\n\"It's going to be a great vice president, meaning a person that can do a fantastic job as president, because you always have to think of that first,\" he said.\n\n\"And then, second, somebody that helps you get elected. And there's nothing wrong with that.\"\n\nEver the consummate showman, Trump has been ramping up the intrigue, sending out a \"long list\" of contenders early on and offering conflicting accounts of how far along he was in the selection process.\n\nThere was speculation that he might use his first public appearance in 11 days to announce Rubio as he addressed supporters at his Doral golf club, on the outskirts of Miami.\n\nHe namechecked the senator, who was in the front row, several times but was silent on his thinking for the veepstakes.\n\n- Casting call -\n\nTrump could have dropped his big reveal at any point in the days before Milwaukee, except that the news would have interrupted arguably one of the worst weeks in the career of his 81-year-old rival Joe Biden.\n\nThe veteran Democrat is facing calls to drop out of the race after a widely-panned debate performance against Trump raised questions about the mental capacity of America's oldest-ever president.\n\n\"The big danger right now is because all the attention is focused on Biden, that if you announce anything, it will get lost,\" Republican strategist Rob Burgess, who worked on the Trump 2016 and 2020 campaigns, told AFP.\n\nMore from this section Scarsdale, Rye top list of wealthiest suburbs in U.S. Report finds deficiencies with Westchester's Bee-Line Bus service Watch Sacramento Kings welcome six-time All-Star DeMar DeRozan\n\nOne of the biggest factors for Trump will be his running mate's fund-raising prowess, and the contenders have all been under pressure to showcase their connections with wealthy mega-donors.\n\nMeanwhile, the campaign has ensured that they are booked regularly for cable news interviews -- a kind of casting call that allows Trump to assess how they look in front of the cameras, a priority for the former reality TV star.\n\nTrump said before the June 27 debate that he already knew who his running mate would be, noting that his pick would likely be attending that night.\n\nThe three frontrunners were all bused to the CNN studio in Atlanta along with some less-favored hopefuls to watch from a volleyball court before being sent in to pitch for Trump on the press line.\n\n- Big role? -\n\nPolitical analyst Donald Nieman said he expected Vance to get the nod as an articulate messenger for Trumpism who is seen as a draw for working class white men in the crucial swing states of Pennsylvania, Michigan and Wisconsin.\n\nBut he added that a less \"thin-skinned\" Trump might have been persuaded to go with Nikki Haley, a one-time UN ambassador who was his last-standing rival in the nominating contest.\n\n\"She would bring Republican defectors and suburban women to Trump -- something he needs,\" Nieman, a history professor at Binghamton University in New York state, told AFP.\n\n\"But he won't because she hasn't signaled abject loyalty and a willingness to submerge her own identity.\"\n\nHaley, who says she is supporting Trump, has not been invited to the convention, according to Politico.\n\nIt remains to be seen in any case whether the successful candidate has what it takes to succeed where Mike Pence failed, and use the job as a springboard to the presidency.\n\n\"I'm not at all convinced that whoever Trump's vice president is, that he or she will have as significant a role as many of their predecessors,\" said constitutional expert Joel Goldstein, of Saint Louis University in Missouri.\n\n\"Although the vice president's role has grown, ultimately it depends upon the president's personality and his or her leadership
